Title : [The Invisible Man]150-the invisible man

Author : [H. G. Wells]70-h. g. wells

CHAPTER I. [THE STRANGE MAN]151-the strange man S ARRIVAL

[The stranger]152-the stranger came early in February , one wintry day , through a biting wind and a driving snow , the last snowfall of the year , over the down , walking from [Bramblehurst railway station]153-bramblehurst railway station , and carrying a little black portmanteau in [his]152-the stranger thickly gloved hand . [He]152-the stranger was wrapped up from head to foot , and the brim of [his]152-the stranger soft felt hat hid every inch of [his]152-the stranger face but the shiny tip of [his]152-the stranger nose ; the snow had piled itself against [his]152-the stranger shoulders and chest , and added a white crest to the burden [he]152-the stranger carried . [He]152-the stranger staggered into the " Coach and Horses "[152-the stranger] more dead than alive , and flung [his]152-the stranger portmanteau down . " A fire , "[152-the stranger] [he]152-the stranger cried , " in the name of [human charity]1414-human charity ! [A room]1415-a room and a fire ! "[152-the stranger] [He]152-the stranger stamped and shook the snow from off [himself]152-the stranger in [the bar]154-the bar , and followed [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall into [[her]71-mrs. hall guest parlour]155-her guest parlour to strike [his]152-the stranger bargain . And with that much introduction , that and a couple of sovereigns flung upon the table , [he]152-the stranger took up [[his]152-the stranger quarters in [the inn]157-the inn]156-his quarters in the inn .

[Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall lit the fire and left [him]152-the stranger there while [she]71-mrs. hall went to prepare [him]152-the stranger a meal with [her]71-mrs. hall own hands . [A guest]158-a guest to stop at [Iping]4-iping in the wintertime was an unheard - of piece of luck , let alone [a guest who was no " haggler]1416-a guest who was no " haggler , "[71-mrs. hall] and [she]71-mrs. hall was resolved to show [herself]71-mrs. hall worthy of [her]71-mrs. hall good fortune . As soon as the bacon was well under way , and [Millie]72-millie , [[her]71-mrs. hall lymphatic maid]159-her lymphatic maid , had been brisked up a bit by a few deftly chosen expressions of contempt , [she]72-millie carried the cloth , plates , and glasses into [the parlour]160-the parlour and began to lay them with the utmost _ clat _ . Although the fire was burning up briskly , [she]72-millie was surprised to see that [[her]72-millie visitor]161-her visitor still wore [his]152-the stranger hat and coat , standing with [his]152-the stranger back to [her]72-millie and staring out of the window at the falling snow in [the yard]162-the yard . [His]152-the stranger gloved hands were clasped behind [him]152-the stranger , and [he]152-the stranger seemed to be lost in thought . [She]72-millie noticed that the melting snow that still sprinkled [his]152-the stranger shoulders dripped upon [her]72-millie carpet . " Can [I]72-millie take [your]152-the stranger hat and coat , [sir]1417-sir ? "[72-millie] [she]72-millie said , " and give [them]1418-them a good dry in [the kitchen]1419-the kitchen ? "[72-millie]

" No , "[152-the stranger] [he]152-the stranger said without turning .

[She]72-millie was not sure [she]72-millie had heard [him]152-the stranger , and was about to repeat [her]72-millie question .

[He]152-the stranger turned [his]152-the stranger head and looked at [her]72-millie over [his]152-the stranger shoulder . " [I]152-the stranger prefer to keep them on , "[152-the stranger] [he]152-the stranger said with emphasis , and [she]72-millie noticed that [he]152-the stranger wore big blue spectacles with sidelights , and had a bush side - whisker over [his]152-the stranger coat - collar that completely hid [his]152-the stranger cheeks and face .

" Very well , [sir]1417-sir , "[72-millie] [she]72-millie said . " _ As _ [you]1417-sir like . In a bit [the room]1421-the room will be warmer . "[72-millie]

[He]152-the stranger made no answer , and had turned [his]152-the stranger face away from [her]72-millie again , and [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall , feeling that [her]72-millie conversational advances were ill - timed , laid the rest of the table things in a quick staccato and whisked out of [the room]1421-the room . When [she]72-millie returned [he]152-the stranger was still standing there , like [a man of stone]164-a man of stone , [his]152-the stranger back hunched , [his]152-the stranger collar turned up , [his]152-the stranger dripping hat - brim turned down , hiding [his]152-the stranger face and ears completely . [She]72-millie put down the eggs and bacon with considerable emphasis , and called rather than said to [him]152-the stranger , " [Your]152-the stranger lunch is served , [sir]1417-sir . "[72-millie]

" Thank [you]72-millie , "[152-the stranger] [he]152-the stranger said at the same time , and did not stir until [she]72-millie was closing the door . Then [he]152-the stranger swung round and approached the table with a certain eager quickness .

As [she]72-millie went behind the bar to [the kitchen]1419-the kitchen [she]72-millie heard a sound repeated at regular intervals . Chirk , chirk , chirk , it went , the sound of a spoon being rapidly whisked round a basin . " [That girl]1423-that girl ! "[72-millie] [she]72-millie said . " There ! [I]72-millie clean forgot it . It s [her]1423-that girl being so long ! "[72-millie] And while [she]72-millie [herself]72-millie finished mixing the mustard , [she]72-millie gave [Millie]72-millie a few verbal stabs for [her]72-millie excessive slowness . [She]72-millie had cooked the ham and eggs , laid the table , and done everything , while [Millie]72-millie ( help indeed ! ) had only succeeded in delaying the mustard . And [him]152-the stranger [a new guest]166-a new guest and wanting to stay ! Then [she]72-millie filled the mustard pot , and , putting it with a certain stateliness upon a gold and black tea - tray , carried it into [the parlour]160-the parlour .

[She]72-millie rapped and entered promptly . As [she]72-millie did so [[her]72-millie visitor]161-her visitor moved quickly , so that [she]72-millie got but a glimpse of a white object disappearing behind the table . It would seem [he]152-the stranger was picking something from the floor . [She]72-millie rapped down the mustard pot on the table , and then [she]72-millie noticed the overcoat and hat had been taken off and put over a chair in front of the fire , and a pair of wet boots threatened rust to [her]72-millie steel fender . [She]72-millie went to these things resolutely . " [I]72-millie suppose [I]72-millie may have them to dry now , "[72-millie] [she]72-millie said in a voice that brooked no denial .

" Leave the hat , "[152-the stranger] said [[her]72-millie visitor]161-her visitor , in a muffled voice , and turning [she]72-millie saw [he]152-the stranger had raised [his]152-the stranger head and was sitting and looking at [her]72-millie .

For a moment [she]72-millie stood gaping at [him]152-the stranger , too surprised to speak .

[He]152-the stranger held a white cloth it was a serviette [he]152-the stranger had brought with [him]152-the stranger over the lower part of [his]152-the stranger face , so that [his]152-the stranger mouth and jaws were completely hidden , and that was the reason of [his]152-the stranger muffled voice . But it was not that which startled [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall . It was the fact that all [his]152-the stranger forehead above [his]152-the stranger blue glasses was covered by a white bandage , and that another covered [his]152-the stranger ears , leaving not a scrap of [his]152-the stranger face exposed excepting only [his]152-the stranger pink , peaked nose . It was bright , pink , and shiny just as it had been at first . [He]152-the stranger wore a dark - brown velvet jacket with a high , black , linen - lined collar turned up about [his]152-the stranger neck . The thick black hair , escaping as it could below and between the cross bandages , projected in curious tails and horns , giving [him]152-the stranger the strangest appearance conceivable . This muffled and bandaged head was so unlike what [she]72-millie had anticipated , that for a moment [she]72-millie was rigid .

[He]152-the stranger did not remove the serviette , but remained holding it , as [she]72-millie saw now , with a brown gloved hand , and regarding [her]72-millie with [his]152-the stranger inscrutable blue glasses . " Leave the hat , "[152-the stranger] [he]152-the stranger said , speaking very distinctly through the white cloth .

[Her]72-millie nerves began to recover from the shock [they]170-they had received . [She]72-millie placed the hat on the chair again by the fire . " [I]72-millie didn t know , [sir]1417-sir , "[72-millie] [she]72-millie began , " that "[72-millie] and [she]72-millie stopped embarrassed .

" Thank [you]72-millie , "[152-the stranger] [he]152-the stranger said drily , glancing from [her]72-millie to the door and then at [her]72-millie again .

" [I]72-millie ll have them nicely dried , [sir]1417-sir , at once , "[72-millie] [she]72-millie said , and carried [his]152-the stranger clothes out of [the room]1421-the room . [She]72-millie glanced at [his]152-the stranger white - swathed head and blue goggles again as [she]72-millie was going out of the door ; but [his]152-the stranger napkin was still in front of [his]152-the stranger face . [She]72-millie shivered a little as [she]72-millie closed the door behind [her]72-millie , and [her]72-millie face was eloquent of [her]72-millie surprise and perplexity . " [I]72-millie _ never _ , "[72-millie] [she]72-millie whispered . " [There]1426-there ! "[72-millie] [She]72-millie went quite softly to [the kitchen]1419-the kitchen , and was too preoccupied to ask [Millie]72-millie what [she]72-millie was messing about with _ now _ , when [she]72-millie got [there]1426-there .

[The visitor]174-the visitor sat and listened to [her]72-millie retreating feet . [He]152-the stranger glanced inquiringly at the window before [he]152-the stranger removed [his]152-the stranger serviette , and resumed [his]152-the stranger meal . [He]152-the stranger took a mouthful , glanced suspiciously at the window , took another mouthful , then rose and , taking the serviette in [his]152-the stranger hand , walked across [the room]1421-the room and pulled the blind down to the top of the white muslin that obscured the lower panes . This left [the room]1421-the room in a twilight . This done , [he]152-the stranger returned with an easier air to the table and [his]152-the stranger meal .

" [The poor soul s]1427-the poor soul s had an accident or an op ration or somethin , "[71-mrs. hall] said [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall . " What a turn [them]1428-them bandages did give [me]71-mrs. hall , to be sure ! "[71-mrs. hall]

[She]71-mrs. hall put on some more coal , unfolded the clothes - horse , and extended the traveller s coat upon this . " And they goggles ! Why , [he]152-the stranger looked more like [a divin helmet]1429-a divin helmet than [a human man]1430-a human man ! "[71-mrs. hall] [She]71-mrs. hall hung [his]152-the stranger muffler on a corner of the horse . " And holding that handkerchief over [his]152-the stranger mouth all the time . Talkin through it ! ... Perhaps [his]152-the stranger mouth was hurt too maybe . "[71-mrs. hall]

[She]71-mrs. hall turned round , as one who suddenly remembers . " Bless [my]71-mrs. hall soul alive ! "[71-mrs. hall] [she]71-mrs. hall said , going off at a tangent ; " ain t [you]152-the stranger done them taters _ yet _ , [Millie]72-millie ? "[71-mrs. hall]

When [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall went to clear away [the stranger]152-the stranger s lunch , [her]71-mrs. hall idea that [his]152-the stranger mouth must also have been cut or disfigured in the accident [she]71-mrs. hall supposed [him]152-the stranger to have suffered , was confirmed , for [he]152-the stranger was smoking a pipe , and all the time that [she]71-mrs. hall was in [the room]1421-the room [he]152-the stranger never loosened the silk muffler [he]152-the stranger had wrapped round the lower part of [his]152-the stranger face to put the mouthpiece to [his]152-the stranger lips . Yet it was not forgetfulness , for [she]71-mrs. hall saw [he]152-the stranger glanced at it as it smouldered out . [He]152-the stranger sat in the corner with [his]152-the stranger back to the window - blind and spoke now , having eaten and drunk and being comfortably warmed through , with less aggressive brevity than before . The reflection of the fire lent a kind of red animation to [his]152-the stranger big spectacles they had lacked hitherto .

" [I]152-the stranger have some luggage , "[152-the stranger] [he]152-the stranger said , " at [Bramblehurst station]3-bramblehurst , "[152-the stranger] and [he]152-the stranger asked [her]71-mrs. hall how [he]152-the stranger could have it sent . [He]152-the stranger bowed [his]152-the stranger bandaged head quite politely in acknowledgment of [her]71-mrs. hall explanation . " To - morrow ? "[152-the stranger] [he]152-the stranger said . " There is [no speedier delivery]1431-no speedier delivery ? "[152-the stranger] and seemed quite disappointed when [she]71-mrs. hall answered , " No . "[71-mrs. hall] Was [she]71-mrs. hall quite sure ? [No man with a trap who would go over]179-no man with a trap who would go over ?

[Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall , nothing loath , answered [his]152-the stranger questions and developed a conversation . " It s [a steep road by the down]1432-a steep road by the down , [sir]1417-sir , "[71-mrs. hall] [she]71-mrs. hall said in answer to the question about a trap ; and then , snatching at an opening , said , " It was there [a carriage]1434-a carriage was upsettled , a year ago and more . [A gentleman]1435-a gentleman killed , besides [[his]1435-a gentleman coachman]1436-his coachman . Accidents , [sir]1417-sir , happen in a moment , don t [they]1438-they ? "[71-mrs. hall]

But [the visitor]174-the visitor was not to be drawn so easily . " [They]1438-they do , "[152-the stranger] [he]152-the stranger said through [his]152-the stranger muffler , eyeing [her]71-mrs. hall quietly through [his]152-the stranger impenetrable glasses .

" But [they]1438-they take long enough to get well , don t [they]1438-they ? ... There was [[[my]152-the stranger sister]1439-my sister s son]1440-my sister s son , [Tom]73-mr. marvel , jest cut [his]1440-my sister s son arm with a scythe , tumbled on it in the ayfield , and , bless [me]152-the stranger ! [he]1440-my sister s son was three months tied up [sir]1417-sir . [You]71-mrs. hall d hardly believe it . It s regular given [me]152-the stranger a dread of a scythe , [sir]1417-sir . "[152-the stranger]

" [I]174-the visitor can quite understand that , "[174-the visitor] said [the visitor]174-the visitor .

" [He]1440-my sister s son was afraid , one time , that [he]1440-my sister s son d have to have an op ration [he]1440-my sister s son was that bad , [sir]1417-sir . "[152-the stranger]

[The visitor]174-the visitor laughed abruptly , a bark of a laugh that [he]174-the visitor seemed to bite and kill in [his]174-the visitor mouth . " _ Was _ [he]1440-my sister s son ? "[174-the visitor] [he]174-the visitor said .

" [He]1440-my sister s son was , [sir]1417-sir . And no laughing matter to [them]1445-them as had the doing for [him]1440-my sister s son , as [I]174-the visitor had [[my]174-the visitor sister]1439-my sister being took up with [her]1439-my sister little ones so much . There was bandages to do , [sir]1417-sir , and bandages to undo . So that if [I]174-the visitor may make so bold as to say it , [sir]1417-sir "[174-the visitor]

" Will [you]71-mrs. hall get [me]174-the visitor some matches ? "[174-the visitor] said [the visitor]174-the visitor , quite abruptly . " [My]174-the visitor pipe is out . "[174-the visitor]

[Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall was pulled up suddenly . It was certainly rude of [him]174-the visitor , after telling [him]174-the visitor all [she]71-mrs. hall had done . [She]71-mrs. hall gasped at [him]174-the visitor for a moment , and remembered [the two sovereigns]184-the two sovereigns . [She]71-mrs. hall went for the matches .

" Thanks , "[174-the visitor] [he]174-the visitor said concisely , as [she]71-mrs. hall put them down , and turned [his]174-the visitor shoulder upon [her]71-mrs. hall and stared out of the window again . It was altogether too discouraging . Evidently [he]174-the visitor was sensitive on the topic of operations and bandages . [She]71-mrs. hall did not " make so bold as to say , "[174-the visitor] however , after all . But [his]174-the visitor snubbing way had irritated [her]71-mrs. hall , and [Millie]72-millie had a hot time of it that afternoon .

[The visitor]174-the visitor remained in [the parlour]160-the parlour until four o clock , without giving the ghost of an excuse for an intrusion . For the most part [he]174-the visitor was quite still during that time ; it would seem [he]174-the visitor sat in the growing darkness smoking in the firelight perhaps dozing .

Once or twice [a curious listener]187-a curious listener might have heard [him]174-the visitor at the coals , and for the space of five minutes [he]174-the visitor was audible pacing [the room]1421-the room . [He]174-the visitor seemed to be talking to [himself]174-the visitor . Then the armchair creaked as [he]174-the visitor sat down again .

CHAPTER II . [MR . TEDDY HENFREY]74-henfrey S FIRST IMPRESSIONS

At four o clock , when it was fairly dark and [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall was screwing up [her]71-mrs. hall courage to go in and ask [[her]71-mrs. hall visitor]161-her visitor if [he]174-the visitor would take some tea , [Teddy Henfrey]74-henfrey , [the clock - jobber]190-the clock - jobber , came into [the bar]154-the bar . " [My]174-the visitor sakes ! [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall , "[174-the visitor] said [he]174-the visitor , " but this is terrible weather for thin boots ! "[174-the visitor] The snow outside was falling faster .

[Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall agreed , and then noticed [he]174-the visitor had [his]174-the visitor bag with [him]174-the visitor . " Now [you]174-the visitor re here , [Mr. Teddy]74-henfrey , "[71-mrs. hall] said [she]71-mrs. hall , " [I]71-mrs. hall d be glad if [you]174-the visitor d give th old clock in [the parlour]160-the parlour a bit of a look . Tis going , and it strikes well and hearty ; but the hour - hand won t do nuthin but point at six . "[71-mrs. hall]

And leading the way , [she]71-mrs. hall went across to the parlour door and rapped and entered .

[[Her]71-mrs. hall visitor]161-her visitor , [she]71-mrs. hall saw as [she]71-mrs. hall opened the door , was seated in the armchair before the fire , dozing it would seem , with [his]161-her visitor bandaged head drooping on one side . The only light in [the room]1421-the room was the red glow from the fire which lit [his]161-her visitor eyes like adverse railway signals , but left [his]161-her visitor downcast face in darkness and the scanty vestiges of the day that came in through the open door . Everything was ruddy , shadowy , and indistinct to [her]71-mrs. hall , the more so since [she]71-mrs. hall had just been lighting the bar lamp , and [her]71-mrs. hall eyes were dazzled . But for a second it seemed to [her]71-mrs. hall that [the man [she]71-mrs. hall looked at]194-the man she looked at had an enormous mouth wide open a vast and incredible mouth that swallowed the whole of the lower portion of [his]161-her visitor face . It was the sensation of a moment : the white - bound head , the monstrous goggle eyes , and this huge yawn below it . Then [he]161-her visitor stirred , started up in [his]161-her visitor chair , put up [his]161-her visitor hand . [She]71-mrs. hall opened the door wide , so that [the room]1421-the room was lighter , and [she]71-mrs. hall saw [him]161-her visitor more clearly , with the muffler held up to [his]161-her visitor face just as [she]71-mrs. hall had seen [him]161-her visitor hold the serviette before . The shadows , [she]71-mrs. hall fancied , had tricked [her]71-mrs. hall .

" Would [you]161-her visitor mind , [sir]1417-sir , [this man]1451-this man a - coming to look at the clock , [sir]1417-sir ? "[71-mrs. hall] [she]71-mrs. hall said , recovering from the momentary shock .

" Look at the clock ? "[161-her visitor] [he]161-her visitor said , staring round in a drowsy manner , and speaking over [his]161-her visitor hand , and then , getting more fully awake , " certainly . "[161-her visitor]

[Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall went away to get a lamp , and [he]161-her visitor rose and stretched [himself]161-her visitor . Then came the light , and [Mr. Teddy Henfrey]74-henfrey , entering , was confronted by [this bandaged person]196-this bandaged person . [He]74-henfrey was , [he]74-henfrey says , " taken aback . "[74-henfrey]

[Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall was about to leave [the room]1421-the room [she]71-mrs. hall made no conversational advances this time , because [she]71-mrs. hall did not want to be snubbed in front of [Mr. Henfrey]74-henfrey when [[her]71-mrs. hall visitor]161-her visitor asked [her]71-mrs. hall if [she]71-mrs. hall had made any arrangements about [[his]74-henfrey boxes at [Bramblehurst]3-bramblehurst]203-his boxes at bramblehurst . After [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall had left [the room]1421-the room , [he]152-the stranger remained standing in front of the fire , glaring , so [Mr. Henfrey]74-henfrey puts it , at the clock - mending . [Mr. Henfrey]74-henfrey not only took off the hands of the clock , and the face , but extracted the works ; and [he]74-henfrey tried to work in as slow and quiet and unassuming a manner as possible . [He]74-henfrey worked with the lamp close to [him]74-henfrey , and the green shade threw a brilliant light upon [his]74-henfrey hands , and upon the frame and wheels , and left the rest of [the room]1421-the room shadowy . When [he]74-henfrey looked up , coloured patches swam in [his]74-henfrey eyes . Being constitutionally of a curious nature , [he]74-henfrey had removed the works a quite unnecessary proceeding with the idea of delaying [his]74-henfrey departure and perhaps falling into conversation with [the stranger]152-the stranger . But [the stranger]152-the stranger stood there , perfectly silent and still . So still , it got on [Henfrey]74-henfrey s nerves . [He]74-henfrey felt alone in [the room]1421-the room and looked up , and there , grey and dim , was the bandaged head and huge blue lenses staring fixedly , with a mist of green spots drifting in front of them . It was so uncanny to [Henfrey]74-henfrey that for a minute [they]212-they remained staring blankly at [one another]213-one another . Then [Henfrey]74-henfrey looked down again . Very uncomfortable position ! [One]214-one would like to say something . Should [he]74-henfrey remark that the weather was very cold for the time of year ?

[He]74-henfrey looked up as if to take aim with that introductory shot . " The weather "[74-henfrey] [he]74-henfrey began .

And again , " Can t [a man]1463-a man look at [you]74-henfrey ? Ugly ! "[74-henfrey]

[She]71-mrs. hall was all the more inclined to snap at [Hall]71-mrs. hall because [the stranger]152-the stranger was undoubtedly [an unusually strange sort of stranger]235-an unusually strange sort of stranger , and [she]71-mrs. hall was by no means assured about [him]152-the stranger in [her]71-mrs. hall own mind . In the middle of the night [she]71-mrs. hall woke up dreaming of huge white heads like turnips , that came trailing after [her]71-mrs. hall , at the end of interminable necks , and with vast black eyes . But being [a sensible woman]236-a sensible woman , [she]71-mrs. hall subdued [her]71-mrs. hall terrors and turned over and went to sleep again .

CHAPTER III . [THE THOUSAND AND ONE BOTTLES]78-the thousand and one bottles

So it was that on the twenty - ninth day of February , at the beginning of the thaw , [this singular person]237-this singular person fell out of infinity into [Iping village]238-iping village . Next day [his]237-this singular person luggage arrived through the slush and very remarkable luggage it was . There were a couple of trunks indeed , such as [a rational man]239-a rational man might need , but in addition there were a box of books big , fat books , of which some were just in an incomprehensible handwriting and a dozen or more crates , boxes , and cases , containing objects packed in straw , as it seemed to [Hall]71-mrs. hall , tugging with a casual curiosity at the straw glass bottles . [The stranger , muffled in hat , coat , gloves , and wrapper]240-the stranger , muffled in hat , coat , gloves , and wrapper , came out impatiently to meet [[Fearenside]79-fearenside s cart]241-fearenside s cart , while [Hall]71-mrs. hall was having a word or so of gossip preparatory to helping bring [them]242-they in . Out [he]237-this singular person came , not noticing [Fearenside]79-fearenside s dog , who was sniffing in a _ dilettante _ spirit at [Hall]71-mrs. hall s legs . " Come along with those boxes , "[237-this singular person] [he]237-this singular person said . " [I]237-this singular person ve been waiting long enough . "[237-this singular person]

And [he]237-this singular person came down the steps towards the tail of [the cart]243-the cart as if to lay hands on the smaller crate .

No sooner had [Fearenside]79-fearenside s dog caught sight of [him]237-this singular person , however , than it began to bristle and growl savagely , and when [he]237-this singular person rushed down the steps it gave an undecided hop , and then sprang straight at [his]237-this singular person hand . " Whup ! "[71-mrs. hall] cried [Hall]71-mrs. hall , jumping back , for [he]237-this singular person was [no hero with dogs]244-no hero with dogs , and [Fearenside]79-fearenside howled , " Lie down ! "[79-fearenside] and snatched [his]79-fearenside whip .

[They]242-they saw the dog s teeth had slipped the hand , heard a kick , saw the dog execute a flanking jump and get home on [the stranger]152-the stranger s leg , and heard the rip of [his]237-this singular person trousering . Then the finer end of [Fearenside]79-fearenside s whip reached [[his]237-this singular person property]246-his property , and the dog , yelping with dismay , retreated under the wheels of [the waggon]247-the waggon . It was all the business of a swift half - minute . [No one]248-no one spoke , [everyone]249-everyone shouted . [The stranger]152-the stranger glanced swiftly at [his]152-the stranger torn glove and at [his]152-the stranger leg , made as if [he]152-the stranger would stoop to the latter , then turned and rushed swiftly up the steps into [the inn]157-the inn . [They]242-they heard [him]152-the stranger go headlong across [the passage]252-the passage and up the uncarpeted stairs to [[his]152-the stranger bedroom]253-his bedroom .

" [You]152-the stranger brute , [you]152-the stranger ! "[79-fearenside] said [Fearenside]79-fearenside , climbing off the waggon with [his]79-fearenside whip in [his]79-fearenside hand , while the dog watched [him]152-the stranger through the wheel . " Come here , "[79-fearenside] said [Fearenside]79-fearenside " [You]152-the stranger d better . "[79-fearenside]

[Hall]71-mrs. hall had stood gaping . " [He]152-the stranger wuz bit , "[71-mrs. hall] said [Hall]71-mrs. hall . " [I]152-the stranger d better go and see to en , "[152-the stranger] and [he]152-the stranger trotted after [the stranger]152-the stranger . [He]152-the stranger met [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall in [the passage]252-the passage . " Carrier s darg , "[152-the stranger] [he]152-the stranger said " bit en . "[152-the stranger]

[He]152-the stranger went straight [upstairs]256-upstairs , and [the stranger]152-the stranger s door being ajar , [he]152-the stranger pushed it open and was entering without any ceremony , being of a naturally sympathetic turn of mind .

The blind was down and [the room]1421-the room dim . [He]152-the stranger caught a glimpse of a most singular thing , what seemed a handless arm waving towards [him]152-the stranger , and a face of three huge indeterminate spots on white , very like the face of a pale pansy . Then [he]152-the stranger was struck violently in the chest , hurled back , and the door slammed in [his]152-the stranger face and locked . It was so rapid that it gave [him]152-the stranger no time to observe . A waving of indecipherable shapes , a blow , and a concussion . There [he]152-the stranger stood on [the dark little landing]259-the dark little landing , wondering what it might be that [he]152-the stranger had seen .

A couple of minutes after , [he]152-the stranger rejoined [the little group that had formed outside [the " Coach and Horses]1476-the " coach and horses]1475-the little group that had formed outside the " coach and horses . "[1476-the " coach and horses] There was [Fearenside]79-fearenside telling about it all over again for the second time ; there was [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall saying [his]79-fearenside dog didn t have no business to bite [[her]71-mrs. hall guests]260-her guests ; there was [Huxter]80-mr. huxter , [the general dealer from over [the road]262-the road]261-the general dealer from over the road , interrogative ; and [Sandy Wadgers]81-mr. wadgers from [the forge]263-the forge , judicial ; besides [women]1471-women and [children]265-children , all of [them]266-them saying fatuities : " Wouldn t let [en]1477-en bite _ [me]266-them _ , [I]266-them knows "[266-them] ; " Tasn t right _ have _ such dargs "[266-them] ; " Whad _ e _ bite n for , then ? "[266-them] and so forth .

[Mr. Hall]77-mr. hall , staring at [them]266-them from the steps and listening , found it incredible that [he]77-mr. hall had seen anything so very remarkable happen [upstairs]256-upstairs . Besides , [his]77-mr. hall vocabulary was altogether too limited to express [his]77-mr. hall impressions .

" [He]77-mr. hall don t want no help , [he]77-mr. hall says , "[77-mr. hall] [he]77-mr. hall said in answer to [[his]77-mr. hall wife]226-his wife s inquiry . " [We]1478-we d better be a - takin of [his]77-mr. hall luggage in . "[77-mr. hall]

" [He]77-mr. hall ought to have it cauterised at once , "[80-mr. huxter] said [Mr. Huxter]80-mr. huxter ; " especially if it s at all inflamed . "[80-mr. huxter]

" [I]269-a lady in the group d shoot en , that s what [I]269-a lady in the group d do , "[269-a lady in the group] said [a lady in the group]269-a lady in the group .

Suddenly the dog began growling again .

" Come along , "[270-the muffled stranger] cried an angry voice in the doorway , and there stood [the muffled stranger]270-the muffled stranger with [his]270-the muffled stranger collar turned up , and [his]270-the muffled stranger hat - brim bent down . " The sooner [you]270-the muffled stranger get those things in the better [I]271-an anonymous bystander ll be pleased . "[271-an anonymous bystander] It is stated by [an anonymous bystander]271-an anonymous bystander that [his]270-the muffled stranger trousers and gloves had been changed .

" Was [you]152-the stranger hurt , [sir]1417-sir ? "[79-fearenside] said [Fearenside]79-fearenside . " [I]79-fearenside m rare sorry the darg "[79-fearenside]

" Not a bit , "[152-the stranger] said [the stranger]152-the stranger . " Never broke the skin . Hurry up with those things . "[152-the stranger]

[He]152-the stranger then swore to [himself]152-the stranger , so [Mr. Hall]77-mr. hall asserts .

Directly the first crate was , in accordance with [his]152-the stranger directions , carried into [the parlour]160-the parlour , [the stranger]152-the stranger flung [himself]152-the stranger upon it with extraordinary eagerness , and began to unpack it , scattering the straw with an utter disregard of [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall s carpet . And from it [he]152-the stranger began to produce bottles little fat bottles containing powders , small and slender bottles containing coloured and white fluids , fluted blue bottles labeled Poison , bottles with round bodies and slender necks , large green - glass bottles , large white - glass bottles , bottles with glass stoppers and frosted labels , bottles with fine corks , bottles with bungs , bottles with wooden caps , wine bottles , salad - oil bottles putting them in rows on the chiffonnier , on the mantel , on the table under the window , round the floor , on the bookshelf everywhere . [The chemist s shop in [Bramblehurst]3-bramblehurst]275-the chemist s shop in bramblehurst could not boast half so many . Quite a sight it was . Crate after crate yielded bottles , until all six were empty and the table high with straw ; the only things that came out of these crates besides the bottles were a number of test - tubes and a carefully packed balance .

And directly the crates were unpacked , [the stranger]152-the stranger went to the window and set to work , not troubling in the least about the litter of straw , the fire which had gone out , the box of books outside , nor for the trunks and other luggage that had gone [upstairs]256-upstairs .

When [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall took [his]152-the stranger dinner in to [him]152-the stranger , [he]152-the stranger was already so absorbed in [his]152-the stranger work , pouring little drops out of the bottles into test - tubes , that [he]152-the stranger did not hear [her]71-mrs. hall until [she]71-mrs. hall had swept away the bulk of the straw and put the tray on the table , with some little emphasis perhaps , seeing the state that the floor was in . Then [he]152-the stranger half turned [his]152-the stranger head and immediately turned it away again . But [she]71-mrs. hall saw [he]152-the stranger had removed [his]152-the stranger glasses ; they were beside [him]152-the stranger on the table , and it seemed to [her]71-mrs. hall that [his]152-the stranger eye sockets were extraordinarily hollow . [He]152-the stranger put on [his]152-the stranger spectacles again , and then turned and faced [her]71-mrs. hall . [She]71-mrs. hall was about to complain of the straw on the floor when [he]152-the stranger anticipated [her]71-mrs. hall .

" [I]152-the stranger wish [you]71-mrs. hall wouldn t come in without knocking , "[152-the stranger] [he]152-the stranger said in the tone of abnormal exasperation that seemed so characteristic of [him]152-the stranger .

" [I]152-the stranger knocked , but seemingly "[152-the stranger]

" Perhaps [you]71-mrs. hall did . But in [my]152-the stranger investigations [my]152-the stranger really very urgent and necessary investigations the slightest disturbance , the jar of a door [I]152-the stranger must ask [you]71-mrs. hall "[152-the stranger]

" Certainly , [sir]1417-sir . [You]71-mrs. hall can turn the lock if [you]71-mrs. hall re like that , [you]71-mrs. hall know . Any time . "[152-the stranger]

" A very good idea , "[152-the stranger] said [the stranger]152-the stranger .

" This stror , [sir]1417-sir , if [I]152-the stranger might make so bold as to remark "[152-the stranger]

" Don t. If the straw makes trouble put it down in the bill . "[152-the stranger] And [he]152-the stranger mumbled at [her]71-mrs. hall words suspiciously like curses .

[He]152-the stranger was so odd , standing there , so aggressive and explosive , bottle in one hand and test - tube in the other , that [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall was quite alarmed . But [she]71-mrs. hall was [a resolute woman]279-a resolute woman . " In which case , [I]71-mrs. hall should like to know , [sir]1417-sir , what [you]1417-sir consider "[71-mrs. hall]

" A shilling put down a shilling . Surely a shilling s enough ? "[152-the stranger]

" So be it , "[71-mrs. hall] said [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall , taking up the table - cloth and beginning to spread it over the table . " If [you]1417-sir re satisfied , of course "[71-mrs. hall]

[He]152-the stranger turned and sat down , with [his]152-the stranger coat - collar toward [her]71-mrs. hall .

All the afternoon [he]152-the stranger worked with the door locked and , as [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall testifies , for the most part in silence . But once there was a concussion and a sound of bottles ringing together as though the table had been hit , and the smash of a bottle flung violently down , and then a rapid pacing athwart [the room]1421-the room . [Fearing]281-fearing " something was the matter , "[71-mrs. hall] [she]71-mrs. hall went to the door and listened , not caring to knock .

" [I]152-the stranger can t go on , "[152-the stranger] [he]152-the stranger was raving . " [I]152-the stranger _ can t _ go on . Three hundred thousand , four hundred thousand ! The huge multitude ! Cheated ! All [my]152-the stranger life it may take [me]152-the stranger ! ... Patience ! Patience indeed ! [... Fool]1483-... fool ! [fool]1484-fool ! "[152-the stranger]

There was a noise of hobnails on the bricks in [the bar]154-the bar , and [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall had very reluctantly to leave the rest of [his]152-the stranger soliloquy . When [she]71-mrs. hall returned [the room]1421-the room was silent again , save for the faint crepitation of [his]152-the stranger chair and the occasional clink of a bottle . It was all over ; [the stranger]152-the stranger had resumed work .

When [she]71-mrs. hall took in [his]152-the stranger tea [she]71-mrs. hall saw broken glass in the corner of [the room]1421-the room under the concave mirror , and a golden stain that had been carelessly wiped . [She]71-mrs. hall called attention to it .

" Put it down in the bill , "[161-her visitor] snapped [[her]71-mrs. hall visitor]161-her visitor . " For God s sake don t worry [me]152-the stranger . If there s damage done , put it down in the bill , "[152-the stranger] and [he]152-the stranger went on ticking a list in the exercise book before [him]152-the stranger .

" [I]79-fearenside ll tell [you]161-her visitor something , "[79-fearenside] said [Fearenside]79-fearenside , mysteriously . It was late in the afternoon , and [they]287-they were in [the little beer - shop of Iping Hanger]288-the little beer - shop of iping hanger .

CHAPTER IV . > [MR . CUSS]82-cuss INTERVIEWS [THE STRANGER]152-the stranger

[I]0-disguised have told the circumstances of [the stranger]152-the stranger s arrival in [Iping]4-iping with a certain fulness of detail , in order that the curious impression [he]152-the stranger created may be understood by [the reader]291-the reader . But excepting two odd incidents , the circumstances of [his]152-the stranger stay until the extraordinary day of the club festival may be passed over very cursorily . There were a number of skirmishes with [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall on matters of domestic discipline , but in every case until late April , when the first signs of penury began , [he]152-the stranger over - rode [her]71-mrs. hall by the easy expedient of an extra payment . [Hall]71-mrs. hall did not like [him]152-the stranger , and whenever [he]152-the stranger dared [he]152-the stranger talked of the advisability of getting rid of [him]152-the stranger ; but [he]152-the stranger showed [his]152-the stranger dislike chiefly by concealing it ostentatiously , and avoiding [[his]152-the stranger visitor]292-his visitor as much as possible . " Wait till the summer , "[71-mrs. hall] said [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall sagely , " when the artisks are beginning to come . Then [we]1486-we ll see . [He]152-the stranger may be a bit overbearing , but [bills settled punctual]1487-bills settled punctual is bills settled punctual , whatever [you]71-mrs. hall d like to say . "[71-mrs. hall]

[The stranger]152-the stranger did not go to [church]294-church , and indeed made no difference between Sunday and the irreligious days , even in costume . [He]152-the stranger worked , as [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall thought , very fitfully . Some days [he]152-the stranger would come down early and be continuously busy . On [others]295-others [he]152-the stranger would rise late , pace [[his]152-the stranger room]296-his room , fretting audibly for hours together , smoke , sleep in the armchair by the fire . Communication with [the world beyond [the village]216-the village]297-the world beyond the village [he]152-the stranger had none . [His]152-the stranger temper continued very uncertain ; for the most part [his]152-the stranger manner was that of [a man suffering under almost unendurable provocation]299-a man suffering under almost unendurable provocation , and once or twice things were snapped , torn , crushed , or broken in spasmodic gusts of violence . [He]152-the stranger seemed under a chronic irritation of the greatest intensity . [His]152-the stranger habit of talking to [himself]152-the stranger in a low voice grew steadily upon [him]152-the stranger , but though [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall listened conscientiously [she]71-mrs. hall could make neither head nor tail of what [she]71-mrs. hall heard .

[He]152-the stranger rarely went abroad by daylight , but at twilight [he]152-the stranger would go out muffled up invisibly , whether the weather were cold or not , and [he]152-the stranger chose the loneliest paths and those most overshadowed by trees and banks . [His]152-the stranger goggling spectacles and ghastly bandaged face under the penthouse of [his]152-the stranger hat , came with a disagreeable suddenness out of the darkness upon [one or two home - going labourers]300-one or two home - going labourers , and [Teddy Henfrey]74-henfrey , tumbling out of the " Scarlet Coat "[74-henfrey] one night , at half - past nine , was scared shamefully by [the stranger]152-the stranger s skull - like head ( [he]152-the stranger was walking hat in hand ) lit by the sudden light of the opened inn door . [Such children]302-such children as saw [him]152-the stranger at nightfall dreamt of bogies , and it seemed doubtful whether [he]152-the stranger disliked [boys]303-boys more than [they]303-boys disliked [him]152-the stranger , or the reverse ; but there was certainly a vivid enough dislike on either side .

It was inevitable that [a person of so remarkable an appearance and bearing]304-a person of so remarkable an appearance and bearing should form a frequent topic in [such a village]305-such a village as [Iping]4-iping . Opinion was greatly divided about [his]152-the stranger occupation . [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall was sensitive on the point . When questioned , [she]71-mrs. hall explained very carefully that [he]152-the stranger was [an " experimental investigator]1488-an " experimental investigator , "[71-mrs. hall] going gingerly over the syllables as one who dreads pitfalls . When asked what [an experimental investigator]1455-an experimental investigator was , [she]71-mrs. hall would say with a touch of superiority that [most educated people]307-most educated people knew such things as that , and would thus explain that [he]152-the stranger " discovered things . "[71-mrs. hall] [[Her]71-mrs. hall visitor]161-her visitor had had an accident , [she]71-mrs. hall said , which temporarily discoloured [his]152-the stranger face and hands , and being of a sensitive disposition , [he]152-the stranger was averse to any public notice of the fact .

Out of [her]71-mrs. hall hearing there was a view largely entertained that [he]152-the stranger was a criminal trying to escape from justice by wrapping [himself]152-the stranger up so as to conceal [himself]152-the stranger altogether from the eye of [the police]1465-the police . This idea sprang from the brain of [Mr. Teddy Henfrey]74-henfrey . No crime of any magnitude dating from the middle or end of February was known to have occurred . Elaborated in the imagination of [Mr. Gould]84-mr. gould , [the probationary assistant in [the National School]311-the national school]310-the probationary assistant in the national school , this theory took the form that [the stranger]152-the stranger was [an Anarchist in disguise , preparing explosives]313-an anarchist in disguise , preparing explosives , and [he]152-the stranger resolved to undertake such detective operations as [his]152-the stranger time permitted . These consisted for the most part in looking very hard at [the stranger]152-the stranger whenever [they]315-they met , or in asking [people who had never seen]316-people who had never seen [the stranger]152-the stranger , leading questions about [him]152-the stranger . But [he]152-the stranger detected nothing .

[Another school of opinion]318-another school of opinion followed [Mr. Fearenside]79-fearenside , and either accepted the piebald view or some modification of it ; as , for instance , [Silas Durgan]85-silas durgan , who was heard to assert that " if [he]85-silas durgan chooses to show enself at fairs [he]85-silas durgan d make [his]85-silas durgan fortune in no time , "[85-silas durgan] and being a bit of [a theologian]319-a theologian , compared [the stranger]152-the stranger to [the man with the one talent]321-the man with the one talent . Yet another view explained the entire matter by regarding [the stranger]152-the stranger as [a harmless lunatic]323-a harmless lunatic . That had the advantage of accounting for everything straight away .

Between [these main groups]324-these main groups there were [waverers]325-waverers and [compromisers]326-compromisers . [Sussex folk]327-sussex folk have few superstitions , and it was only after the events of early [April]86-april that the thought of the supernatural was first whispered in [the village]216-the village . Even then it was only credited among [the women folk]329-the women folk .

But whatever [they]329-the women folk thought of [him]152-the stranger , [[people]330-people in [Iping]4-iping]331-people in iping , on the whole , agreed in disliking [him]152-the stranger . [His]152-the stranger irritability , though it might have been comprehensible to [an urban brain - worker]332-an urban brain - worker , was an amazing thing to [these quiet Sussex villagers]333-these quiet sussex villagers . The frantic gesticulations [they]329-the women folk surprised now and then , the headlong pace after nightfall that swept [him]152-the stranger upon [them]329-the women folk round quiet corners , the inhuman bludgeoning of all tentative advances of curiosity , the taste for twilight that led to the closing of doors , the pulling down of blinds , the extinction of candles and lamps who could agree with such goings on ? [They]329-the women folk drew aside as [he]152-the stranger passed down [the village]216-the village , and when [he]152-the stranger had gone by , [young humourists]335-young humourists would up with coat - collars and down with hat - brims , and go pacing nervously after [him]152-the stranger in imitation of [his]152-the stranger occult bearing . There was a song popular at that time called " [The Bogey Man]87-the bogey man "[336-one or two of the villagers] . [Miss Statchell]88-miss statchell sang it at the schoolroom concert ( in aid of the church lamps ) , and thereafter whenever [one or two of [the villagers]337-the villagers]336-one or two of the villagers were gathered together and [the stranger]152-the stranger appeared , a bar or so of this tune , more or less sharp or flat , was whistled in the midst of [them]337-the villagers . [Also belated little children]339-also belated little children would call " [Bogey Man]87-the bogey man ! "[339-also belated little children] after [him]152-the stranger , and make off tremulously elated .

[Cuss]82-cuss , [the general practitioner]340-the general practitioner , was devoured by curiosity .
