CHAPTER V. THE BURGLARY AT [THE VICARAGE]358-the vicarage

The facts of the burglary at [the vicarage]358-the vicarage came to [us]360-us chiefly through the medium of [the vicar]353-the vicar and [[his]353-the vicar wife]226-his wife . It occurred in the small hours of [Whit Monday]8-whit monday , the day devoted in Iping to the Club festivities . [Mrs. Bunting]89-mrs. bunting , it seems , woke up suddenly in the stillness that comes before the dawn , with the strong impression that the door of [[their]363-their bedroom]364-their bedroom had opened and closed . [She]89-mrs. bunting did not arouse [[her]89-mrs. bunting husband]365-her husband at first , but sat up in bed listening . [She]89-mrs. bunting then distinctly heard the pad , pad , pad of bare feet coming out of [the adjoining dressing - room]366-the adjoining dressing - room and walking along [the passage]252-the passage towards the staircase . As soon as [she]89-mrs. bunting felt assured of this , [she]89-mrs. bunting aroused [the Rev. Mr. Bunting]90-mr. bunting as quietly as possible . [He]365-her husband did not strike a light , but putting on [his]365-her husband spectacles , [her]89-mrs. bunting dressing - gown and [his]365-her husband bath slippers , [he]365-her husband went out on [the landing]368-the landing to listen . [He]365-her husband heard quite distinctly a fumbling going on at [his]365-her husband study desk down - [stairs]369-stairs , and then a violent sneeze .

At that [he]365-her husband returned to [[his]365-her husband bedroom]253-his bedroom , armed [himself]365-her husband with the most obvious weapon , the poker , and descended the staircase as noiselessly as possible . [Mrs. Bunting]89-mrs. bunting came out on [the landing]368-the landing .

The hour was about four , and the ultimate darkness of the night was past . There was a faint shimmer of light in [the hall]346-the hall , but the study doorway yawned impenetrably black . Everything was still except the faint creaking of the stairs under [Mr. Bunting]90-mr. bunting s tread , and the slight movements in [the study]373-the study . Then something snapped , the drawer was opened , and there was a rustle of papers . Then came an imprecation , and a match was struck and [the study]373-the study was flooded with yellow light . [Mr. Bunting]90-mr. bunting was now in [the hall]346-the hall , and through the crack of the door [he]90-mr. bunting could see the desk and the open drawer and a candle burning on the desk . But the robber [he]365-her husband could not see . [He]365-her husband stood there in [the hall]346-the hall undecided what to do , and [Mrs. Bunting]89-mrs. bunting , [her]89-mrs. bunting face white and intent , crept slowly [downstairs]377-downstairs after [him]365-her husband . One thing kept [Mr. Bunting]90-mr. bunting s courage ; the persuasion that [this burglar]378-this burglar was [a resident in [the village]216-the village]379-a resident in the village .

[They]381-they heard the chink of money , and realised that [the robber]382-the robber had found the housekeeping reserve of gold two pounds ten in half sovereigns altogether . At that sound [Mr. Bunting]90-mr. bunting was nerved to abrupt action . Gripping the poker firmly , [he]90-mr. bunting rushed into [the room]1421-the room , closely followed by [Mrs. Bunting]89-mrs. bunting . " Surrender ! "[90-mr. bunting] cried [Mr. Bunting]90-mr. bunting , fiercely , and then stooped amazed . Apparently [the room]1421-the room was perfectly empty .

Yet [their]381-they conviction that [they]381-they had , that very moment , heard somebody moving in [the room]1421-the room had amounted to a certainty . For half a minute , perhaps , [they]381-they stood gaping , then [Mrs. Bunting]89-mrs. bunting went across [the room]1421-the room and looked behind the screen , while [Mr. Bunting]90-mr. bunting , by a kindred impulse , peered under the desk . Then [Mrs. Bunting]89-mrs. bunting turned back the window - curtains , and [Mr. Bunting]90-mr. bunting looked up the chimney and probed it with the poker . Then [Mrs. Bunting]89-mrs. bunting scrutinised the waste - paper basket and [Mr. Bunting]90-mr. bunting opened the lid of the coal - scuttle . Then [they]381-they came to a stop and stood with eyes interrogating [each other]387-each other .

" [I]90-mr. bunting could have sworn "[90-mr. bunting] said [Mr. Bunting]90-mr. bunting .

" The candle ! "[90-mr. bunting] said [Mr. Bunting]90-mr. bunting . " Who lit the candle ? "[90-mr. bunting]

" The drawer ! "[89-mrs. bunting] said [Mrs. Bunting]89-mrs. bunting . " And the money s gone ! "[89-mrs. bunting]

[She]89-mrs. bunting went hastily to the doorway .

" Of all the strange occurrences "[90-mr. bunting]

There was a violent sneeze in [the passage]252-the passage . [They]381-they rushed out , and as [they]381-they did so the kitchen door slammed . " Bring the candle , "[90-mr. bunting] said [Mr. Bunting]90-mr. bunting , and led the way . [They]381-they both heard a sound of bolts being hastily shot back .

As [he]90-mr. bunting opened the kitchen door [he]90-mr. bunting saw through [the scullery]389-the scullery that the back door was just opening , and the faint light of early dawn displayed the dark masses of [the garden beyond]390-the garden beyond . [He]90-mr. bunting is certain that nothing went out of the door . It opened , stood open for a moment , and then closed with a slam . As it did so , the candle [Mrs. Bunting]89-mrs. bunting was carrying from [the study]373-the study flickered and flared . It was a minute or more before [they]381-they entered [the kitchen]1419-the kitchen .

[The place]351-the place was empty . [They]381-they refastened the back door , examined [the kitchen]1419-the kitchen , pantry , and scullery thoroughly , and at last went down into [the cellar]395-the cellar . There was not a soul to be found in [the house]396-the house , search as [they]381-they would .

[Daylight]91-daylight found [the vicar]353-the vicar and [[his]353-the vicar wife]226-his wife , [a quaintly - costumed little couple , still marvelling about on [[their]381-they own ground floor]400-their own ground floor]399-a quaintly - costumed little couple , still marvelling about on their own ground floor by the unnecessary light of a guttering candle .

CHAPTER VI . THE FURNITURE THAT WENT MAD

Now it happened that in the early hours of [Whit Monday]8-whit monday , before [Millie]72-millie was hunted out for the day , [Mr. Hall]77-mr. hall and [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall both rose and went noiselessly down into [the cellar]395-the cellar . [Their]381-they business there was of a private nature , and had something to do with the specific gravity of [their]381-they beer . [They]381-they had hardly entered [the cellar]395-the cellar when [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall found [she]71-mrs. hall had forgotten to bring down a bottle of sarsaparilla from [[their]381-they joint - room]403-their joint - room . As [she]71-mrs. hall was [the expert and principal operator in this affair]404-the expert and principal operator in this affair , [Hall]71-mrs. hall very properly went [upstairs]256-upstairs for it .

On [the landing]368-the landing [he]77-mr. hall was surprised to see that the stranger s door was ajar . [He]77-mr. hall went on into [[his]77-mr. hall own room]407-his own room and found the bottle as [he]77-mr. hall had been directed .

But returning with the bottle , [he]77-mr. hall noticed that the bolts of the front door had been shot back , that the door was in fact simply on the latch . And with a flash of inspiration [he]77-mr. hall connected this with [[the stranger]152-the stranger s room]409-the stranger s room [upstairs]256-upstairs and the suggestions of [Mr. Teddy Henfrey]74-henfrey . [He]77-mr. hall distinctly remembered holding the candle while [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall shot these bolts overnight . At the sight [he]77-mr. hall stopped , gaping , then with the bottle still in [his]77-mr. hall hand went [upstairs]256-upstairs again . [He]77-mr. hall rapped at [the stranger]152-the stranger s door . There was no answer . [He]77-mr. hall rapped again ; then pushed the door wide open and entered .

It was as [he]77-mr. hall expected . The bed , [the room]1421-the room also , was empty . And what was stranger , even to [his]77-mr. hall heavy intelligence , on the bedroom chair and along the rail of the bed were scattered the garments , the only garments so far as [he]77-mr. hall knew , and the bandages of [[their]414-their guest]415-their guest . [His]77-mr. hall big slouch hat even was cocked jauntily over the bed - post .

As [Hall]71-mrs. hall stood there [he]77-mr. hall heard [[his]77-mr. hall wife]226-his wife s voice coming out of the depth of [the cellar]395-the cellar , with that rapid telescoping of the syllables and interrogative cocking up of the final words to a high note , by which [the West Sussex villager]418-the west sussex villager is wo nt to indicate a brisk impatience . " [George]92-george ! [You]92-george gart whad a wand ? "[77-mr. hall]

At that [he]77-mr. hall turned and hurried down to [her]226-his wife . " [Janny]93-janny , "[77-mr. hall] [he]77-mr. hall said , over the rail of [the cellar steps]419-the cellar steps , " tas the truth what [Henfrey]74-henfrey sez . [E]74-henfrey s not in [uz room]1499-uz room , [e]74-henfrey en t. And the front door s onbolted . "[77-mr. hall]

At first [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall did not understand , and as soon as [she]71-mrs. hall did [she]71-mrs. hall resolved to see [the empty room]420-the empty room for [herself]71-mrs. hall . [Hall]71-mrs. hall , still holding the bottle , went first . " If [e]74-henfrey en t there , "[77-mr. hall] [he]77-mr. hall said , " is close are . And what s [e]74-henfrey doin ithout is close , then ? Tas a most curious business . "[77-mr. hall]

As [they]421-they came up [the cellar steps]419-the cellar steps [they]421-they both , it was afterwards ascertained , fancied [they]421-they heard the front door open and shut , but seeing it closed and nothing there , [neither]423-neither said a word to [the other]424-the other about it at the time . [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall passed [[her]71-mrs. hall husband]365-her husband in [the passage]252-the passage and ran on first [upstairs]256-upstairs . [Someone]428-someone sneezed on the staircase . [Hall]71-mrs. hall , following six steps behind , thought that [he]77-mr. hall heard [her]428-someone sneeze . [She]71-mrs. hall , going on first , was under the impression that [Hall]71-mrs. hall was sneezing . [She]71-mrs. hall flung open the door and stood regarding [the room]1421-the room . " Of [all the curious]1500-all the curious ! "[71-mrs. hall] [she]71-mrs. hall said .

[She]71-mrs. hall heard a sniff close behind [her]71-mrs. hall head as it seemed , and turning , was surprised to see [Hall]71-mrs. hall a dozen feet off on [the topmost stair]430-the topmost stair . But in another moment [he]77-mr. hall was beside [her]71-mrs. hall . [She]71-mrs. hall bent forward and put [her]71-mrs. hall hand on the pillow and then under the clothes .

" Cold , "[71-mrs. hall] [she]71-mrs. hall said . " [He]77-mr. hall s been up this hour or more . "[71-mrs. hall]

As [she]71-mrs. hall did so , a most extraordinary thing happened . The bed - clothes gathered themselves together , leapt up suddenly into a sort of peak , and then jumped headlong over the bottom rail . It was exactly as if a hand had clutched them in the centre and flung them aside . Immediately after , [the stranger]152-the stranger s hat hopped off the bed - post , described a whirling flight in the air through the better part of a circle , and then dashed straight at [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall s face . Then as swiftly came the sponge from [the washstand]432-the washstand ; and then the chair , flinging [the stranger]152-the stranger s coat and trousers carelessly aside , and laughing drily in a voice singularly like [the stranger s]434-the stranger s , turned itself up with its four legs at [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall , seemed to take aim at [her]71-mrs. hall for a moment , and charged at [her]71-mrs. hall . [She]71-mrs. hall screamed and turned , and then the chair legs came gently but firmly against [her]71-mrs. hall back and impelled [her]71-mrs. hall and [Hall]71-mrs. hall out of [the room]1421-the room . The door slammed violently and was locked . The chair and bed seemed to be executing a dance of triumph for a moment , and then abruptly everything was still .

[Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall was left almost in a fainting condition in [Mr. Hall]77-mr. hall s arms on [the landing]368-the landing . It was with the greatest difficulty that [Mr. Hall]77-mr. hall and [Millie]72-millie , who had been roused by [her]71-mrs. hall scream of alarm , succeeded in getting [her]71-mrs. hall [downstairs]377-downstairs , and applying the restoratives customary in such cases .

" Tas sperits , "[71-mrs. hall] said [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall . " [I]71-mrs. hall know tas sperits . [I]71-mrs. hall ve read in papers of en . Tables and chairs leaping and dancing ... "[71-mrs. hall]

" Take a drop more , [Janny]93-janny , "[71-mrs. hall] said [Hall]71-mrs. hall . " Twill steady [ye]93-janny . "[71-mrs. hall]

" Lock [him]77-mr. hall out , "[71-mrs. hall] said [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall . " Don t let [him]77-mr. hall come in again . [I]71-mrs. hall half guessed [I]71-mrs. hall might ha known . With [them]1501-them goggling eyes and bandaged head , and never going to [church of a Sunday]1502-church of a sunday . And all [they]1501-them bottles more n it s right for [any one]1485-any one to have . [He]77-mr. hall s put the sperits into the furniture .... [My]71-mrs. hall good old furniture ! Twas in that very chair [[my]71-mrs. hall poor dear mother]1504-my poor dear mother used to sit when [I]71-mrs. hall was [a little girl]1505-a little girl . To think it should rise up against [me]71-mrs. hall now ! "[71-mrs. hall]

" Just a drop more , [Janny]93-janny , "[71-mrs. hall] said [Hall]71-mrs. hall . " [Your]93-janny nerves is all upset . "[71-mrs. hall]

[They]438-they sent [Millie]72-millie across [the street]439-the street through the golden five o clock sunshine to rouse up [Mr. Sandy Wadgers]81-mr. wadgers , [the blacksmith]440-the blacksmith . [Mr. Hall]77-mr. hall s compliments and the furniture [upstairs]256-upstairs was behaving most extraordinary . Would [Mr. Wadgers]81-mr. wadgers come round ? [He]81-mr. wadgers was [a knowing man]442-a knowing man , was [Mr. Wadgers]81-mr. wadgers , and very resourceful . [He]81-mr. wadgers took quite a grave view of the case . " [Arm]94-arm darmed if thet ent witchcraft , "[81-mr. wadgers] was the view of [Mr. Sandy Wadgers]81-mr. wadgers . " [You]438-they warnt horseshoes for such gentry as [he]81-mr. wadgers . "[81-mr. wadgers]

[He]81-mr. wadgers came round greatly concerned . [They]438-they wanted [him]81-mr. wadgers to lead the way [upstairs]256-upstairs to [the room]1421-the room , but [he]81-mr. wadgers didn t seem to be in any hurry . [He]81-mr. wadgers preferred to talk in [the passage]252-the passage . Over the way [[Huxter]80-mr. huxter s apprentice]446-huxter s apprentice came out and began taking down the shutters of the tobacco window . [He]446-huxter s apprentice was called over to join the discussion . [Mr. Huxter]80-mr. huxter naturally followed over in the course of a few minutes . The Anglo - Saxon genius for [parliamentary government]447-parliamentary government asserted itself ; there was a great deal of talk and no decisive action . " Let s have the facts first , "[81-mr. wadgers] insisted [Mr. Sandy Wadgers]81-mr. wadgers . " [Let]438-they s be sure [we]438-they d be acting perfectly right in bustin that there door open . A door onbust is always open to bustin , but [ye]1506-ye can t onbust a door once [you]1506-ye ve busted en . "[81-mr. wadgers]

And suddenly and most wonderfully the door of [the room upstairs]448-the room upstairs opened of its own accord , and as [they]438-they looked up in amazement , [they]438-they saw descending the stairs the muffled figure of [the stranger]152-the stranger staring more blackly and blankly than ever with those unreasonably large blue glass eyes of [his]152-the stranger . [He]152-the stranger came down stiffly and slowly , staring all the time ; [he]152-the stranger walked across [the passage]252-the passage staring , then stopped .

" Look there ! "[152-the stranger] [he]152-the stranger said , and [their]438-they eyes followed the direction of [his]152-the stranger gloved finger and saw a bottle of sarsaparilla hard by the cellar door . Then [he]152-the stranger entered [the parlour]160-the parlour , and suddenly , swiftly , viciously , slammed the door in [their]438-they faces .

Not a word was spoken until the last echoes of the slam had died away . [They]438-they stared at [one another]213-one another . " Well , if that don t lick everything ! "[81-mr. wadgers] said [Mr. Wadgers]81-mr. wadgers , and left the alternative unsaid .

" [I]81-mr. wadgers d go in and ask n bout it , "[81-mr. wadgers] said [Wadgers]81-mr. wadgers , to [Mr. Hall]77-mr. hall . " [I]81-mr. wadgers d d mand an explanation . "[81-mr. wadgers]

It took some time to bring [[the landlady]453-the landlady s husband]454-the landlady s husband up to that pitch . At last [he]152-the stranger rapped , opened the door , and got as far as , " Excuse [me]152-the stranger "[152-the stranger]

" Go to the devil ! "[152-the stranger] said [the stranger]152-the stranger in a tremendous voice , and " Shut that door after [you]77-mr. hall . "[152-the stranger] So that brief interview terminated .

CHAPTER VII . THE UNVEILING OF [THE STRANGER]152-the stranger

[The stranger]152-the stranger went into [the little parlour of the " Coach and [Horses]1508-horses]1507-the little parlour of the " coach and horses "[152-the stranger] about half - past five in the morning , and there [he]152-the stranger remained until near midday , the blinds down , the door shut , and none , after [Hall]77-mr. hall s repulse , venturing near [him]152-the stranger .

All that time [he]152-the stranger must have fasted . Thrice [he]152-the stranger rang [his]152-the stranger bell , the third time furiously and continuously , but [no one]248-no one answered [him]152-the stranger . " [Him]152-the stranger and [his]152-the stranger go to the devil indeed ! "[71-mrs. hall] said [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall . Presently came an imperfect rumour of the burglary at [the vicarage]358-the vicarage , and [two and two]460-two and two were put together . [Hall]71-mrs. hall , assisted by [Wadgers]81-mr. wadgers , went off to find [Mr. Shuckleforth]95-mr. shuckleforth , [the magistrate]461-the magistrate , and take [his]95-mr. shuckleforth advice . [No one]248-no one ventured [upstairs]256-upstairs . How [the stranger]152-the stranger occupied [himself]152-the stranger is unknown . Now and then [he]152-the stranger would stride violently up and down , and twice came an outburst of curses , a tearing of paper , and a violent smashing of bottles .

[The little group of scared but curious people]465-the little group of scared but curious people increased . [Mrs. Huxter]96-mrs. huxter came over ; [some gay young fellows]466-some gay young fellows resplendent in black ready - made jackets and _ piqu _ paper ties for it was [Whit Monday]8-whit monday joined [the group]467-the group with confused interrogations . [Young Archie Harker]98-young archie harker distinguished [himself]98-young archie harker by going up [the yard]162-the yard and trying to peep under the window - blinds . [He]98-young archie harker could see nothing , but gave reason for supposing that [he]98-young archie harker did , and [others of the Iping youth]469-others of the iping youth presently joined [him]98-young archie harker .

It was the finest of all possible [Whit Mondays]9-whit mondays , and down [the village street]470-the village street stood [a row of nearly a dozen booths]471-a row of nearly a dozen booths , [a shooting gallery]472-a shooting gallery , and on the grass by [the forge]263-the forge were three yellow and chocolate waggons and [some picturesque strangers of both sexes putting up a cocoanut shy]474-some picturesque strangers of both sexes putting up a cocoanut shy . [The gentlemen]475-the gentlemen wore blue jerseys , [the ladies]476-the ladies white aprons and quite fashionable hats with heavy plumes . [Wodger]99-wodger , of the " Purple Fawn , "[100-mr. jaggers] and [Mr. Jaggers]100-mr. jaggers , [the cobbler , who also sold old second - hand ordinary bicycles]477-the cobbler , who also sold old second - hand ordinary bicycles , were stretching a string of [union - jacks and royal ensigns]478-union - jacks and royal ensigns ( which had originally celebrated the first Victorian Jubilee ) across [the road]262-the road .

And inside , in the artificial darkness of [the parlour]160-the parlour , into which only one thin jet of sunlight penetrated , [the stranger]152-the stranger , hungry [we]482-we must suppose , and fearful , hidden in [his]152-the stranger uncomfortable hot wrappings , pored through [his]152-the stranger dark glasses upon [his]152-the stranger paper or chinked [his]152-the stranger dirty little bottles , and occasionally swore savagely at [the boys]483-the boys , audible if invisible , outside the windows . In the corner by the fireplace lay the fragments of half a dozen smashed bottles , and a pungent twang of chlorine tainted the air . So much [we]482-we know from what was heard at the time and from what was subsequently seen in [the room]1421-the room .

About noon [he]152-the stranger suddenly opened [his]152-the stranger parlour door and stood glaring fixedly at [the three or four people in the bar]485-the three or four people in the bar . " [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall , "[152-the stranger] [he]152-the stranger said . [Somebody]486-somebody went sheepishly and called for [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall .

[Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall appeared after an interval , a little short of breath , but all the fiercer for that . [Hall]71-mrs. hall was still out . [She]71-mrs. hall had deliberated over this scene , and [she]71-mrs. hall came holding a little tray with an unsettled bill upon it . " Is it [your]152-the stranger bill [you]152-the stranger re wanting , [sir]1417-sir ? "[71-mrs. hall] [she]71-mrs. hall said .

" Why wasn t [my]71-mrs. hall breakfast laid ? Why haven t [you]152-the stranger prepared [my]71-mrs. hall meals and answered [my]71-mrs. hall bell ? Do [you]152-the stranger think [I]71-mrs. hall live without eating ? "[71-mrs. hall]

" Why isn t [my]71-mrs. hall bill paid ? "[71-mrs. hall] said [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall . " That s what [I]71-mrs. hall want to know . "[71-mrs. hall]

" [I]71-mrs. hall told [you]152-the stranger three days ago [I]71-mrs. hall was awaiting a remittance "[71-mrs. hall]

" [I]71-mrs. hall told [you]152-the stranger two days ago [I]71-mrs. hall wasn t going to await no remittances . [You]152-the stranger can t grumble if [your]152-the stranger breakfast waits a bit , if [my]71-mrs. hall bill s been waiting these five days , can [you]152-the stranger ? "[71-mrs. hall]

[The stranger]152-the stranger swore briefly but vividly .

" Nar , nar ! "[71-mrs. hall] from [the bar]154-the bar .

" And [I]71-mrs. hall d thank [you]152-the stranger kindly , [sir]1417-sir , if [you]152-the stranger d keep [your]152-the stranger swearing to [yourself]152-the stranger , [sir]1417-sir , "[71-mrs. hall] said [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall .

[The stranger]152-the stranger stood looking more like [an angry diving - helmet]490-an angry diving - helmet than ever . It was universally felt in [the bar]154-the bar that [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall had the better of [him]152-the stranger . [His]152-the stranger next words showed as much .

" Look here , [[my]152-the stranger good woman]1512-my good woman "[152-the stranger] [he]152-the stranger began .

" [Don t good woman _ [me]71-mrs. hall _]1513-don t good woman _ me _ , "[71-mrs. hall] said [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall .

" [I]490-an angry diving - helmet ve told [you]152-the stranger [my]490-an angry diving - helmet remittance hasn t come . "[490-an angry diving - helmet]

" Remittance indeed ! "[71-mrs. hall] said [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall .

" Still , [I]490-an angry diving - helmet daresay in [my]490-an angry diving - helmet pocket "[490-an angry diving - helmet]

" [You]152-the stranger told [me]152-the stranger three days ago that [you]152-the stranger hadn t anything but a sovereign s worth of silver upon [you]152-the stranger . "[152-the stranger]

" Well , [I]490-an angry diving - helmet ve found some more "[490-an angry diving - helmet]

" [Ul - lo]101-ul - lo ! "[152-the stranger] from [the bar]154-the bar .

" [I]71-mrs. hall wonder where [you]152-the stranger found it , "[71-mrs. hall] said [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall .

That seemed to annoy [the stranger]152-the stranger very much . [He]152-the stranger stamped [his]152-the stranger foot . " What do [you]71-mrs. hall mean ? "[152-the stranger] [he]152-the stranger said .

" That [I]71-mrs. hall wonder where [you]152-the stranger found it , "[71-mrs. hall] said [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall . " And before [I]71-mrs. hall take any bills or get any breakfasts , or do any such things whatsoever , [you]152-the stranger got to tell [me]71-mrs. hall one or two things [I]71-mrs. hall don t understand , and what [nobody]1514-nobody don t understand , and what [everybody]1515-everybody is very anxious to understand . [I]71-mrs. hall want to know what [you]152-the stranger been doing t [[my]71-mrs. hall chair [upstairs]256-upstairs]1516-my chair upstairs , and [I]71-mrs. hall want to know how tis [[your]152-the stranger room]1518-your room was empty , and how [you]152-the stranger got in again . [Them]1519-them as stops in [this house]1520-this house comes in by the doors that s the rule of [the house]396-the house , and that [you]152-the stranger _ didn t _ do , and what [I]71-mrs. hall want to know is how [you]152-the stranger _ did _ come in . And [I]71-mrs. hall want to know "[71-mrs. hall]

Suddenly [the stranger]152-the stranger raised [his]152-the stranger gloved hands clenched , stamped [his]152-the stranger foot , and said , " Stop ! "[152-the stranger] with such extraordinary violence that [he]152-the stranger silenced [her]495-you instantly .

" [You]495-you don t understand , "[152-the stranger] [he]152-the stranger said , " who [I]152-the stranger am or what [I]152-the stranger am . [I]152-the stranger ll show [you]495-you . By Heaven ! [I]152-the stranger ll show [you]495-you . "[152-the stranger] Then [he]152-the stranger put [his]152-the stranger open palm over [his]152-the stranger face and withdrew it . The centre of [his]152-the stranger face became a black cavity . " Here , "[152-the stranger] [he]152-the stranger said . [He]152-the stranger stepped forward and handed [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall something which [she]71-mrs. hall , staring at [his]152-the stranger metamorphosed face , accepted automatically . Then , when [she]71-mrs. hall saw what it was , [she]71-mrs. hall screamed loudly , dropped it , and staggered back . The nose it was [the stranger]152-the stranger s nose ! pink and shining rolled on the floor .

Then [he]152-the stranger removed [his]152-the stranger spectacles , and [everyone in [the bar]154-the bar]497-everyone in the bar gasped . [He]152-the stranger took off [his]152-the stranger hat , and with a violent gesture tore at [his]152-the stranger whiskers and bandages . For a moment [they]499-they resisted [him]152-the stranger . A flash of horrible anticipation passed through [the bar]154-the bar . " Oh , [[my]501-some one Gard]1522-my gard ! "[501-some one] said [some one]501-some one . Then off [they]499-they came .

It was worse than anything . [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall , standing open - mouthed and horror - struck , shrieked at what [she]71-mrs. hall saw , and made for the door of [the house]396-the house . [Everyone]249-everyone began to move . [They]249-everyone were prepared for scars , disfigurements , tangible horrors , but nothing ! The bandages and false hair flew across [the passage]252-the passage into the bar , making a hobbledehoy jump to avoid [them]499-they . [Everyone]249-everyone tumbled on [everyone else]506-everyone else down the steps . For [the man who stood there shouting some incoherent explanation]507-the man who stood there shouting some incoherent explanation , was a solid gesticulating figure up to the coat - collar of [him]152-the stranger , and then nothingness , no visible thing at all !

[People down [the village]216-the village]508-people down the village heard shouts and shrieks , and looking up [the street]439-the street saw the " Coach and Horses "[508-people down the village] violently firing out its humanity . [They]508-people down the village saw [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall fall down and [Mr. Teddy Henfrey]74-henfrey jump to avoid tumbling over [her]71-mrs. hall , and then [they]508-people down the village heard the frightful screams of [Millie]72-millie , who , emerging suddenly from [the kitchen]1419-the kitchen [at the noise of the tumult]512-at the noise of the tumult , had come upon [the headless stranger from behind]513-the headless stranger from behind . These increased suddenly .

Forthwith [everyone all down [the street]439-the street]514-everyone all down the street , [the sweetstuff seller]516-the sweetstuff seller , [cocoanut shy proprietor]517-cocoanut shy proprietor and [[his]517-cocoanut shy proprietor assistant]518-his assistant , [the swing man]519-the swing man , [little boys]520-little boys and [girls]521-girls , [rustic dandies]522-rustic dandies , [smart wenches , smocked elders and aproned gipsies]523-smart wenches , smocked elders and aproned gipsies began running towards [the inn]157-the inn , and in a miraculously short space of time [a crowd of perhaps forty people]525-a crowd of perhaps forty people , and rapidly increasing , swayed and hooted and inquired and exclaimed and suggested , in front of [[Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall s establishment]526-mrs. hall s establishment . [Everyone]249-everyone seemed eager to talk at once , and the result was [Babel]102-babel . A small group supported [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall , who was picked up in a state of collapse . There was a conference , and the incredible evidence of [a vociferous eye - witness]528-a vociferous eye - witness . " [O Bogey]87-the bogey man ! "[529-the crowd] " What s [he]517-cocoanut shy proprietor been doin , then ? "[529-the crowd] " Ain t hurt [the girl]1523-the girl , as [e]517-cocoanut shy proprietor ? "[529-the crowd] " Run at en with a knife , [I]529-the crowd believe . "[529-the crowd] " No ed , [I]529-the crowd tell [ye]517-cocoanut shy proprietor . [I]529-the crowd don t mean no manner of speaking . [I]529-the crowd mean _ marn ithout a ed _ ! "[529-the crowd] " Narnsense ! tis some conjuring trick . "[529-the crowd] " Fetched off is wrapping , [e]517-cocoanut shy proprietor did "[529-the crowd]

In its struggles to see in through the open door , [the crowd]529-the crowd formed [itself]529-the crowd into a straggling wedge , with [the more adventurous apex nearest [the inn]157-the inn]530-the more adventurous apex nearest the inn . " [He]517-cocoanut shy proprietor stood for a moment , [I]529-the crowd heerd the gal scream , and [he]517-cocoanut shy proprietor turned . [I]529-the crowd saw [her]1523-the girl skirts whisk , and [he]517-cocoanut shy proprietor went after [her]1523-the girl . Didn t take ten seconds . Back [he]517-cocoanut shy proprietor comes with a knife in uz hand and a loaf ; stood just as if [he]517-cocoanut shy proprietor was staring . Not a moment ago . Went in that there door . [I]529-the crowd tell [e]529-the crowd , [e]529-the crowd ain t gart no ed at all . [You]529-the crowd just missed en "[529-the crowd]

There was a disturbance behind , and [the speaker]532-the speaker stopped to step aside for a little procession that was marching very resolutely towards [the house]396-the house ; first [Mr. Hall]77-mr. hall , very red and determined , then [Mr. Bobby Jaffers]103-jaffers , [the village constable]534-the village constable , and then [the wary Mr. Wadgers]81-mr. wadgers . [They]535-they had come now armed with a warrant .

[The others]566-the others , following incontinently , were jammed for a moment in the corner by the doorway . The hitting continued . [Phipps]106-phipps , [the Unitarian]567-the unitarian , had a front tooth broken , and [Henfrey]74-henfrey was injured in the cartilage of [his]74-henfrey ear . " [I]103-jaffers got [him]103-jaffers ! "[103-jaffers] shouted [Jaffers]103-jaffers , choking and reeling through [them]1515-everybody all , and wrestling with purple face and swelling veins against [[his]103-jaffers unseen enemy]571-his unseen enemy .

[Men]572-men staggered right and left as [the extraordinary conflict]573-the extraordinary conflict swayed swiftly towards [the house]396-the house door , and went spinning down the half - dozen steps of [the inn]157-the inn . There were excited cries of " Hold [him]105-the invisible man ! "[576-a young fellow] " Invisible ! "[576-a young fellow] and so forth , and [a young fellow]576-a young fellow , [a stranger in the place whose name did not come to light]577-a stranger in the place whose name did not come to light , rushed in at once , caught something , missed [his]576-a young fellow hold , and fell over [the constable s prostrate body]578-the constable s prostrate body . For a space [people]330-people stood amazed and gesticulating , and then came panic , and scattered [them]330-people abroad through [the village]216-the village as a gust scatters dead leaves .

But [Jaffers]103-jaffers lay quite still , face upward and knees bent , at the foot of the steps of [the inn]157-the inn .

CHAPTER VIII . IN TRANSIT

The eighth chapter is exceedingly brief , and relates that [Gibbons]107-gibbons , [the amateur naturalist of [the district]586-the district]585-the amateur naturalist of the district , while lying out on [the spacious open downs]587-the spacious open downs without a soul within a couple of miles of [him]107-gibbons , as [he]107-gibbons thought , and almost dozing , heard close to [him]107-gibbons the sound as of [a man]1463-a man coughing , sneezing , and then swearing savagely to [himself]1463-a man ; and looking , beheld nothing . Yet the voice was indisputable . [It]589-it continued to swear with that breadth and variety that distinguishes the swearing of [a cultivated man]590-a cultivated man . It grew to a climax , diminished again , and died away in the distance , going as it seemed to [him]107-gibbons in [the direction of [Adderdean]10-adderdean]591-the direction of adderdean . It lifted to a spasmodic sneeze and ended . [Gibbons]107-gibbons had heard nothing of the morning s occurrences , but the phenomenon was so striking and disturbing that [his]107-gibbons philosophical tranquillity vanished ; [he]107-gibbons got up hastily , and hurried down the steepness of [the hill]592-the hill towards [the village]216-the village , as fast as [he]107-gibbons could go .

CHAPTER IX . [MR . THOMAS MARVEL]73-mr. marvel

[You]594-you must picture [Mr. Thomas Marvel]73-mr. marvel as [a person of copious , flexible visage , a nose of cylindrical protrusion , a liquorish , ample , fluctuating mouth , and a beard of bristling eccentricity]595-a person of copious , flexible visage , a nose of cylindrical protrusion , a liquorish , ample , fluctuating mouth , and a beard of bristling eccentricity . [His]73-mr. marvel figure inclined to embonpoint ; [his]73-mr. marvel short limbs accentuated this inclination . [He]73-mr. marvel wore a furry silk hat , and the frequent substitution of twine and shoe - laces for buttons , apparent at critical points of [his]73-mr. marvel costume , marked [a man]1463-a man essentially bachelor .

[Mr. Thomas Marvel]73-mr. marvel was sitting with [his]73-mr. marvel feet in a ditch by [the roadside over the down towards [Adderdean]10-adderdean]597-the roadside over the down towards adderdean , about a mile and a half out of [Iping]4-iping . [His]73-mr. marvel feet , save for socks of irregular open - work , were bare , [his]73-mr. marvel big toes were broad , and pricked like the ears of a watchful dog . In a leisurely manner [he]73-mr. marvel did everything in a leisurely manner [he]73-mr. marvel was contemplating trying on a pair of boots . They were the soundest boots [he]73-mr. marvel had come across for a long time , but too large for [him]73-mr. marvel ; whereas the ones [he]73-mr. marvel had were , in dry weather , a very comfortable fit , but too thin - soled for damp . [Mr. Thomas Marvel]73-mr. marvel hated roomy shoes , but then [he]73-mr. marvel hated damp . [He]73-mr. marvel had never properly thought out which [he]73-mr. marvel hated most , and it was a pleasant day , and there was nothing better to do . So [he]73-mr. marvel put the four shoes in a graceful group on the turf and looked at them . And seeing them there among the grass and springing agrimony , it suddenly occurred to [him]73-mr. marvel that both pairs were exceedingly ugly to see . [He]73-mr. marvel was not at all startled by a voice behind [him]73-mr. marvel .

" [They]598-they re boots , anyhow , "[108-the voice] said [the Voice]108-the voice .

" They are charity boots , "[73-mr. marvel] said [Mr. Thomas Marvel]73-mr. marvel , with [his]73-mr. marvel head on one side regarding [them]598-they distastefully ; " and which is the ugliest pair in [the whole blessed universe]1536-the whole blessed universe , [I]73-mr. marvel m darned if [I]73-mr. marvel know ! "[73-mr. marvel]

" H m , "[108-the voice] said [the Voice]108-the voice .

" [I]73-mr. marvel ve worn worse in fact , [I]73-mr. marvel ve worn none . But none so owdacious ugly if [you]1537-you ll allow the expression . [I]73-mr. marvel ve been cadging boots in particular for days . Because [I]73-mr. marvel was sick of _ them _ . They re sound enough , of course . But [a gentleman on tramp]1538-a gentleman on tramp sees such a thundering lot of [his]1538-a gentleman on tramp boots . And if [you]1537-you ll believe [me]73-mr. marvel , [I]73-mr. marvel ve raised nothing in [the whole blessed country]1539-the whole blessed country , try as [I]73-mr. marvel would , but _ them _ . Look at [em]598-they ! And [a good country]1540-a good country for boots , too , in a general way . But it s just [my]73-mr. marvel promiscuous luck . [I]73-mr. marvel ve got [my]73-mr. marvel boots in [this country]1541-this country ten years or more . And then [they]598-they treat [you]1537-you like this . "[73-mr. marvel]

[The Voice]108-the voice made no answer . Whizz came a flint , apparently out of the air , and missed [Mr. Marvel]73-mr. marvel s shoulder by a hair s - breadth . [Mr. Marvel]73-mr. marvel , turning , saw a flint jerk up into the air , trace a complicated path , hang for a moment , and then fling at [his]73-mr. marvel feet with almost invisible rapidity . [He]73-mr. marvel was too amazed to dodge . Whizz it came , and ricochetted from a bare toe into the ditch . [Mr. Thomas Marvel]73-mr. marvel jumped a foot and howled aloud . Then [he]73-mr. marvel started to run , tripped over an unseen obstacle , and came head over heels into a sitting position .

" _ Now _ , "[601-the voice] said [the Voice]601-the voice , as a third stone curved upward and hung in the air above the tramp . " Am [I]601-the voice imagination ? "[601-the voice]

" If [you]73-mr. marvel struggle any more , "[601-the voice] said [the Voice]601-the voice , " [I]601-the voice shall throw the flint at [your]73-mr. marvel head . "[601-the voice]

"[73-mr. marvel]

CHAPTER X. [MR . MARVEL]73-mr. marvel S VISIT TO [IPING]613-iping

After the first gusty panic had spent itself [Iping]4-iping became argumentative . Scepticism suddenly reared [its]4-iping head rather nervous scepticism , not at all assured of [its]4-iping back , but scepticism nevertheless . It is so much easier not to believe in [an invisible man]1549-an invisible man ; and those who had actually seen [him]1549-an invisible man dissolve into air , or felt the strength of [his]1549-an invisible man arm , could be counted on the fingers of two hands . And of [these witnesses]615-these witnesses [Mr. Wadgers]81-mr. wadgers was presently missing , having retired impregnably behind the bolts and bars of [[his]81-mr. wadgers own house]616-his own house , and [Jaffers]103-jaffers was lying stunned in [the parlour of the " Coach and [Horses]110-horses]1567-the parlour of the " coach and horses . "[103-jaffers] Great and strange ideas transcending experience often have less effect upon [men]572-men and [women]1471-women than smaller , more tangible considerations . [Iping]4-iping was gay with bunting , and [everybody]1515-everybody was in gala dress . [Whit Monday]8-whit monday had been looked forward to for a month or more . By the afternoon even [those who believed in [the Unseen]111-the unseen]620-those who believed in the unseen were beginning to resume [their]620-those who believed in the unseen little amusements in a tentative fashion , on the supposition that [he]1549-an invisible man had quite gone away , and with [the sceptics]621-the sceptics [he]1549-an invisible man was already a jest . But [people]330-people , [sceptics]623-sceptics and [believers alike]624-believers alike , were remarkably sociable all that day .

[[Haysman]112-haysman s meadow]625-haysman s meadow was gay with [a tent]626-a tent , in which [Mrs. Bunting]89-mrs. bunting and [other ladies]627-other ladies were preparing tea , while , without , [the Sunday - school children]628-the sunday - school children ran races and played games under the noisy guidance of [the curate]629-the curate and [the Misses Cuss and Sackbut]113-the misses cuss and sackbut . No doubt there was a slight uneasiness in the air , but [people]330-people for the most part had the sense to conceal whatever imaginative qualms [they]330-people experienced . On [the village green]631-the village green an inclined strong [ rope ? ] , down which , clinging the while to a pulley - swung handle , one could be hurled violently against a sack at the other end , came in for considerable favour among [the adolescents]632-the adolescents , as also did the swings and the cocoanut shies . There was also promenading , and the steam organ attached to a small roundabout filled the air with a pungent flavour of oil and with equally pungent music . [Members of the club , who had attended church in the morning]633-members of the club , who had attended church in the morning , were splendid in badges of pink and green , and [some of the gayer - minded]634-some of the gayer - minded had also adorned [their]634-some of the gayer - minded bowler hats with brilliant - coloured favours of ribbon . [Old Fletcher , whose conceptions of holiday - making were severe]635-old fletcher , whose conceptions of holiday - making were severe , was visible through the jasmine about [his]635-old fletcher , whose conceptions of holiday - making were severe window or through the open door ( whichever way [you]636-you chose to look ) , poised delicately on a plank supported on two chairs , and whitewashing the ceiling of [[his]635-old fletcher , whose conceptions of holiday - making were severe front room]637-his front room .

About four o clock [a stranger]1459-a stranger entered [the village]216-the village from [the direction of [the downs]641-the downs]640-the direction of the downs . [He]1459-a stranger was [a short , stout person in an extraordinarily shabby top hat]642-a short , stout person in an extraordinarily shabby top hat , and [he]1459-a stranger appeared to be very much out of breath . [His]1459-a stranger cheeks were alternately limp and tightly puffed . [His]1459-a stranger mottled face was apprehensive , and [he]1459-a stranger moved with a sort of reluctant alacrity . [He]1459-a stranger turned the corner of [the church]643-the church , and directed [his]1459-a stranger way to the " Coach and Horses . "[1459-a stranger] Among others [old Fletcher]114-old fletcher remembers seeing [him]1459-a stranger , and indeed [the old gentleman]644-the old gentleman was so struck by [his]644-the old gentleman peculiar agitation that [he]644-the old gentleman inadvertently allowed a quantity of whitewash to run down the brush into the sleeve of [his]644-the old gentleman coat while regarding [him]644-the old gentleman .

[This stranger]645-this stranger , to the perceptions of [the proprietor of [the cocoanut shy]647-the cocoanut shy]646-the proprietor of the cocoanut shy , appeared to be talking to [himself]645-this stranger , and [Mr. Huxter]80-mr. huxter remarked the same thing . [He]1459-a stranger stopped at the foot of [the " Coach and Horses "[645-this stranger] steps]648-the " coach and horses " steps , and , according to [Mr. Huxter]80-mr. huxter , appeared to undergo a severe internal struggle before [he]1459-a stranger could induce [himself]1459-a stranger to enter [the house]396-the house . [He]1459-a stranger stood looking about [him]1459-a stranger for some moments , and then [Mr. Huxter]80-mr. huxter saw [him]1459-a stranger walk in an oddly furtive manner towards the gates of [the yard]162-the yard , upon which the parlour window opened . [The stranger]152-the stranger , after some hesitation , leant against one of the gate - posts , produced a short clay pipe , and prepared to fill it . [His]152-the stranger fingers trembled while doing so . [He]152-the stranger lit it clumsily , and folding [his]152-the stranger arms began to smoke in a languid attitude , an attitude which [his]152-the stranger occasional glances up [the yard]162-the yard altogether belied .

All this [Mr. Huxter]80-mr. huxter saw over the canisters of the tobacco window , and the singularity of [the man]345-the man s behaviour prompted [him]80-mr. huxter to maintain [his]80-mr. huxter observation .

Presently [the stranger]152-the stranger stood up abruptly and put [his]152-the stranger pipe in [his]152-the stranger pocket . Then [he]152-the stranger vanished into [the yard]162-the yard . Forthwith [Mr. Huxter]80-mr. huxter , conceiving [he]80-mr. huxter was witness of some petty larceny , leapt round [his]80-mr. huxter counter and ran out into [the road]262-the road to intercept [the thief]661-the thief . "[80-mr. huxter] again . [He]80-mr. huxter saw the ground suddenly close to [his]80-mr. huxter face . [The world]547-the world seemed to splash into a million whirling specks of light , and subsequent proceedings interested [him]80-mr. huxter no more .

CHAPTER XII . [THE INVISIBLE MAN]150-the invisible man LOSES [HIS]150-the invisible man TEMPER

It is unavoidable that at this point the narrative should break off again , for a certain very painful reason that will presently be apparent . While these things were going on in [the parlour]160-the parlour , and while [Mr. Huxter]80-mr. huxter was watching [Mr. Marvel]73-mr. marvel smoking [his]80-mr. huxter pipe against the gate , not a dozen yards away were [Mr. Hall]77-mr. hall and [Teddy Henfrey]74-henfrey discussing in a state of cloudy puzzlement the one Iping topic .

Suddenly there came a violent thud against the door of [the parlour]160-the parlour , a sharp cry , and then silence .

" Hul - lo ! "[74-henfrey] said [Teddy Henfrey]74-henfrey .

" [Hul - lo]116-hul - lo ! "[115-tap] from [the Tap]115-tap .

[Mr. Hall]77-mr. hall took things in slowly but surely . " That ain t right , "[77-mr. hall] [he]77-mr. hall said , and came round from behind the bar towards the parlour door .

[He]77-mr. hall and [Teddy]74-henfrey approached the door together , with intent faces . [Their]700-their eyes considered . " Summat wrong , "[77-mr. hall] said [Hall]77-mr. hall , and [Henfrey]74-henfrey nodded agreement . Whiffs of an unpleasant chemical odour met [them]700-their , and there was a muffled sound of conversation , very rapid and subdued .

" [You]74-henfrey all right thur ? "[77-mr. hall] asked [Hall]77-mr. hall , rapping .

The muttered conversation ceased abruptly , for a moment silence , then the conversation was resumed , in hissing whispers , then a sharp cry of " No ! no , [you]77-mr. hall don t ! "[74-henfrey] There came a sudden motion and the oversetting of a chair , a brief struggle . Silence again .

" What the dooce ? "[74-henfrey] exclaimed [Henfrey]74-henfrey , _ sotto voce _ .

" [You]74-henfrey all right thur ? "[77-mr. hall] asked [Mr. Hall]77-mr. hall , sharply , again .

[The Vicar]117-the vicar s voice answered with a curious jerking intonation : " Quite ri - right . Please don t interrupt . "[117-the vicar]

" Odd ! "[74-henfrey] said [Mr. Henfrey]74-henfrey .

[Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall appeared behind the bar . [Hall]71-mrs. hall made gestures of silence and invitation . This aroused [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall s wifely opposition . [Hall]71-mrs. hall tried to convey everything by grimaces and dumb show , but [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall was obdurate . [She]71-mrs. hall raised [her]71-mrs. hall voice . At first [she]71-mrs. hall refused to see anything in what [they]702-they had heard at all . [Everyone]249-everyone stood listening intently . [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall s eyes , directed straight before [her]71-mrs. hall , saw without seeing the brilliant oblong of [the inn]157-the inn door , [the road]262-the road white and vivid , and [[Huxter]80-mr. huxter s shop]706-huxter s shop - front blistering in the June sun . [Hall]71-mrs. hall , [Henfrey]74-henfrey , and [the human contents of the tap]709-the human contents of the tap rushed out at once pell - mell into [the street]439-the street . [They]711-they saw [someone]428-someone whisk round the corner towards [the road]262-the road , and [Mr. Huxter]80-mr. huxter executing a complicated leap in the air that ended on [his]80-mr. huxter face and shoulder . Down [the street]439-the street [people]330-people were standing astonished or running towards [them]711-they .

[Mr. Huxter]80-mr. huxter was stunned . [Henfrey]74-henfrey stopped to discover this , but [Hall]71-mrs. hall and [the two labourers from the Tap]716-the two labourers from the tap rushed at once to the corner , shouting incoherent things , and saw [Mr. Marvel]73-mr. marvel vanishing by the corner of the church wall . [They]711-they appear to have jumped to the impossible conclusion that this was [the Invisible Man]150-the invisible man suddenly become visible , and set off at once along [the lane]718-the lane in pursuit . But [Hall]71-mrs. hall had hardly run a dozen yards before [he]80-mr. huxter gave a loud shout of astonishment and went flying headlong sideways , clutching one of [the labourers]719-the labourers and bringing [him]80-mr. huxter to the ground . [He]80-mr. huxter had been charged just as one charges [a man at football]720-a man at football . [The second labourer]721-the second labourer came round in a circle , stared , and conceiving that [Hall]71-mrs. hall had tumbled over of [his]80-mr. huxter own accord , turned to resume the pursuit , only to be tripped by the ankle just as [Huxter]80-mr. huxter had been . Then , as [the first labourer]722-the first labourer struggled to [his]722-the first labourer feet , [he]722-the first labourer was kicked sideways by a blow that might have felled an ox .

As [he]722-the first labourer went down , the rush from [the direction of [the village green]631-the village green]723-the direction of the village green came round the corner . [The first to appear]725-the first to appear was [the proprietor of [the cocoanut shy]647-the cocoanut shy]646-the proprietor of the cocoanut shy , [a burly man in a blue jersey]728-a burly man in a blue jersey . And then something happened to [his]646-the proprietor of the cocoanut shy rear - most foot , and [he]646-the proprietor of the cocoanut shy went headlong and rolled sideways just in time to graze the feet of [[his]646-the proprietor of the cocoanut shy brother]731-his brother and [partner]732-partner , following headlong . [The two]733-the two were then kicked , knelt on , fallen over , and cursed by [quite a number of over - hasty people]734-quite a number of over - hasty people .

Now when [Hall]71-mrs. hall and [Henfrey]74-henfrey and [the labourers]719-the labourers ran out of [the house]396-the house , [Mrs. Hall]71-mrs. hall , who had been disciplined by years of experience , remained in [the bar next the till]737-the bar next the till . And suddenly the parlour door was opened , and [Mr. Cuss]82-cuss appeared , and without glancing at [her]71-mrs. hall rushed at once down the steps toward the corner . " Hold [him]82-cuss ! [He]82-cuss knew nothing of the existence of [Marvel]73-mr. marvel . For [the Invisible Man]150-the invisible man had handed over the books and bundle in [the yard]162-the yard . [Somebody in full flight]741-somebody in full flight trod heavily on [his]82-cuss finger . [He]82-cuss yelled , struggled to regain [his]82-cuss feet , was knocked against and thrown on all fours again , and became aware that [he]82-cuss was involved not in a capture , but a rout . [Everyone]249-everyone was running back to [the village]216-the village . [He]82-cuss rose again and was hit severely behind the ear . [He]82-cuss staggered and set off back to [the " Coach and Horses]1476-the " coach and horses "[82-cuss] forthwith , leaping over the deserted [Huxter]80-mr. huxter , who was now sitting up , on [his]80-mr. huxter way .

Behind [him]82-cuss as [he]82-cuss was halfway up [the inn steps]744-the inn steps [he]82-cuss heard a sudden yell of rage , rising sharply out of the confusion of cries , and a sounding smack in [someone]428-someone [s]428-someone face . [He]82-cuss recognised the voice as that of [the Invisible Man]150-the invisible man , and the note was that of [a man suddenly infuriated by a painful blow]747-a man suddenly infuriated by a painful blow .

In another moment [Mr. Cuss]82-cuss was back in [the parlour]160-the parlour . " [He]150-the invisible man s coming back , [Bunting]90-mr. bunting ! "[82-cuss] [he]82-cuss said , rushing in . " Save [yourself]90-mr. bunting ! "[82-cuss]

[Mr. Bunting]90-mr. bunting was standing in the window engaged in an attempt to clothe [himself]90-mr. bunting in the hearth - rug and a _ West Surrey Gazette _ . " Who s coming ? "[90-mr. bunting] [he]90-mr. bunting said , so startled that [his]90-mr. bunting costume narrowly escaped disintegration .

" [Invisible Man]1591-invisible man , "[82-cuss] said [Cuss]82-cuss , and rushed on to the window . " [We]1592-we d better clear out from here ! [He]90-mr. bunting s fighting mad ! Mad ! "[82-cuss]

In another moment [he]90-mr. bunting was out in [the yard]162-the yard .

" Good heavens ! "[90-mr. bunting] said [Mr. Bunting]90-mr. bunting , hesitating between two horrible alternatives . [He]90-mr. bunting heard a frightful struggle in the passage of [the inn]157-the inn , and [his]90-mr. bunting decision was made . [He]90-mr. bunting clambered out of the window , adjusted [his]90-mr. bunting costume hastily , and fled up [the village]216-the village as fast as [his]90-mr. bunting fat little legs would carry [him]90-mr. bunting .

From the moment when [the Invisible Man]150-the invisible man screamed with rage and [Mr. Bunting]90-mr. bunting made [his]90-mr. bunting memorable flight up [the village]216-the village , it became impossible to give a consecutive account of affairs in [Iping]4-iping . Possibly [the Invisible Man]105-the invisible man s original intention was simply to cover [Marvel]73-mr. marvel s retreat with the clothes and books . But [his]105-the invisible man temper , at no time very good , seems to have gone completely at some chance blow , and forthwith [he]105-the invisible man set to smiting and overthrowing , for the mere satisfaction of hurting .

[You]754-you must figure [the street]439-the street full of running figures , of doors slamming and fights for hiding - places . [You]754-you must figure the tumult suddenly striking on the unstable equilibrium of [old Fletcher]114-old fletcher s planks and two chairs with cataclysmic results . [You]754-you must figure [an appalled couple caught dismally in a swing]756-an appalled couple caught dismally in a swing . And then the whole tumultuous rush has passed and [the Iping street]757-the iping street with [its]757-the iping street gauds and flags is deserted save for the still raging unseen , and littered with cocoanuts , overthrown canvas screens , and the scattered stock in trade of [a sweetstuff stall]758-a sweetstuff stall . Everywhere there is a sound of closing shutters and shoving bolts , and the only visible humanity is an occasional flitting eye under a raised eyebrow in the corner of a window pane .

[The Invisible Man]150-the invisible man amused [himself]150-the invisible man for a little while by breaking all the windows in [the " Coach and Horses]1476-the " coach and horses , "[150-the invisible man] and then [he]150-the invisible man thrust a street lamp through the parlour window of [Mrs. Gribble]118-mrs. gribble . [He]150-the invisible man it must have been who cut the telegraph wire to [Adderdean]10-adderdean just beyond [Higgins cottage]12-higgins cottage on [the Adderdean road]760-the adderdean road . And after that , as [his]105-the invisible man peculiar qualities allowed , [he]105-the invisible man passed out of human perceptions altogether , and [he]105-the invisible man was neither heard , seen , nor felt in [Iping]4-iping any more . [He]105-the invisible man vanished absolutely .

But it was the best part of two hours before [any human being]761-any human being ventured out again into the desolation of [Iping street]4-iping .

[CHAPTER XIII]14-chapter xiii . [MR . MARVEL DISCUSSES]73-mr. marvel [HIS]73-mr. marvel RESIGNATION

When the dusk was gathering and [Iping]4-iping was just beginning to peep timorously forth again upon the shattered wreckage of [[its]4-iping Bank Holiday]762-its bank holiday , [a short , thick - set man in a shabby silk hat]763-a short , thick - set man in a shabby silk hat was marching painfully through the twilight behind the beechwoods on [the road]262-the road to [Bramblehurst]3-bramblehurst . [He]763-a short , thick - set man in a shabby silk hat carried three books bound together by some sort of ornamental elastic ligature , and a bundle wrapped in a blue table - cloth . [His]105-the invisible man rubicund face expressed consternation and fatigue ; [he]105-the invisible man appeared to be in a spasmodic sort of hurry . [He]105-the invisible man was accompanied by a voice other than [his]105-the invisible man own , and ever and again [he]105-the invisible man winced under the touch of unseen hands .

" If [you]73-mr. marvel give [me]108-the voice the slip again , "[108-the voice] said [the Voice]108-the voice , " if [you]73-mr. marvel attempt to give [me]108-the voice the slip again "[108-the voice]

" [I]73-mr. marvel didn t try to give [you]601-the voice the slip , "[73-mr. marvel] said [Marvel]73-mr. marvel , in a voice that was not far remote from tears . " [I]73-mr. marvel swear [I]73-mr. marvel didn t. [I]73-mr. marvel didn t know the blessed turning , that was all ! How the devil was [I]73-mr. marvel to know the blessed turning ? [He]73-mr. marvel blew out [his]73-mr. marvel cheeks , and [his]73-mr. marvel eyes were eloquent of despair .

" It s bad enough to let these floundering yokels explode [my]73-mr. marvel little secret , without _ [your]73-mr. marvel _ cutting off with [my]73-mr. marvel books . [Mr. Marvel]73-mr. marvel s face assumed a greyish tint between the ruddier patches .

" No ? "[601-the voice]

[CHAPTER XIV]15-chapter xiv . AT [PORT STOWE]16-port stowe

Ten o clock the next morning found [Mr. Marvel]73-mr. marvel , unshaven , dirty , and travel - stained , sitting with the books beside [him]73-mr. marvel and [his]73-mr. marvel hands deep in [his]73-mr. marvel pockets , looking very weary , nervous , and uncomfortable , and inflating [his]73-mr. marvel cheeks at infrequent intervals , on the bench outside [a little inn on [the outskirts of [Port Stowe]16-port stowe]779-the outskirts of port stowe]778-a little inn on the outskirts of port stowe . Beside [him]73-mr. marvel were the books , but now they were tied with string . The bundle had been abandoned in [the pine - woods beyond [Bramblehurst]3-bramblehurst]780-the pine - woods beyond bramblehurst , in accordance with a change in the plans of [the Invisible Man]150-the invisible man . [Mr. Marvel]73-mr. marvel sat on the bench , and although [no one]248-no one took the slightest notice of [him]73-mr. marvel , [his]73-mr. marvel agitation remained at fever heat . [His]73-mr. marvel hands would go ever and again to [his]73-mr. marvel various pockets with a curious nervous fumbling .

When [he]73-mr. marvel had been sitting for the best part of an hour , however , [an elderly mariner]783-an elderly mariner , carrying a newspaper , came out of [the inn]157-the inn and sat down beside [him]73-mr. marvel . " Pleasant day , "[785-the mariner] said [the mariner]785-the mariner .

[Mr. Marvel]73-mr. marvel glanced about [him]785-the mariner with something very like terror . " Very , "[785-the mariner] [he]785-the mariner said .

" Just seasonable weather for the time of year , "[785-the mariner] said [the mariner]785-the mariner , taking no denial .

" Quite , "[73-mr. marvel] said [Mr. Marvel]73-mr. marvel .

[The mariner]785-the mariner produced a toothpick , and ( saving [his]785-the mariner regard ) was engrossed thereby for some minutes . [His]785-the mariner eyes meanwhile were at liberty to examine [Mr. Marvel]73-mr. marvel s dusty figure , and the books beside [him]785-the mariner . As [he]785-the mariner had approached [Mr. Marvel]73-mr. marvel [he]785-the mariner had heard a sound like the dropping of coins into a pocket . [He]785-the mariner was struck by the contrast of [Mr. Marvel]73-mr. marvel s appearance with this suggestion of opulence . Thence [his]785-the mariner mind wandered back again to a topic that had taken a curiously firm hold of [his]785-the mariner imagination .

" Books ? "[785-the mariner] [he]785-the mariner said suddenly , noisily finishing with the toothpick .

[Mr. Marvel]73-mr. marvel started and looked at [them]788-them . " Oh , yes , "[73-mr. marvel] [he]73-mr. marvel said . " Yes , they re books . "[73-mr. marvel]

" There s some extra - ordinary things in books , "[785-the mariner] said [the mariner]785-the mariner .

" [I]73-mr. marvel believe [you]785-the mariner , "[73-mr. marvel] said [Mr. Marvel]73-mr. marvel .

" And some extra - ordinary things out of em , "[785-the mariner] said [the mariner]785-the mariner .

" True likewise , "[73-mr. marvel] said [Mr. Marvel]73-mr. marvel . [He]73-mr. marvel eyed [[his]73-mr. marvel interlocutor]599-his interlocutor , and then glanced about [him]599-his interlocutor .

" There s some extra - ordinary things in newspapers , for example , "[785-the mariner] said [the mariner]785-the mariner .

" There are . "[599-his interlocutor]

" In _ this _ newspaper , "[785-the mariner] said [the mariner]785-the mariner .

" Ah ! "[73-mr. marvel] said [Mr. Marvel]73-mr. marvel .

" There s a story , "[785-the mariner] said [the mariner]785-the mariner , fixing [Mr. Marvel]73-mr. marvel with an eye that was firm and deliberate ; " there s a story about [an Invisible Man]1549-an invisible man , for instance . "[785-the mariner]

[Mr. Marvel]73-mr. marvel pulled [his]73-mr. marvel mouth askew and scratched [his]73-mr. marvel cheek and felt [his]73-mr. marvel ears glowing . " What will [they]1607-they be writing next ? "[73-mr. marvel] [he]73-mr. marvel asked faintly . " [Ostria]17-ostria , or [America]18-america ? "[73-mr. marvel]

The story of the flying money was true . And all about [that neighbourhood]826-that neighbourhood , even from the august [London]20-london and [Country Banking Company]21-country banking company , from the tills of [shops]827-shops and [inns]828-inns doors standing that sunny weather entirely open money had been quietly and dexterously making off that day in handfuls and rouleaux , floating quietly along by walls and shady places , dodging quickly from the approaching eyes of [men]572-men . [CHAPTER XV]22-chapter xv . [THE MAN WHO WAS RUNNING]105-the invisible man

In the early evening time [Dr. Kemp]121-kemp was sitting in [[his]121-kemp study]836-his study in [the belvedere on [the hill overlooking [Burdock]122-port burdock]838-the hill overlooking burdock]837-the belvedere on the hill overlooking burdock . [It]836-his study was [a pleasant little room]839-a pleasant little room , with three windows north , west , and south and bookshelves covered with books and scientific publications , and a broad writing - table , and , under the north window , a microscope , glass slips , minute instruments , some cultures , and scattered bottles of reagents . [Dr. Kemp]121-kemp s solar lamp was lit , albeit the sky was still bright with the sunset light , and [his]121-kemp blinds were up because there was no offence of peering outsiders to require them pulled down . [Dr. Kemp]121-kemp was [a tall and slender young man , with flaxen hair and a moustache almost white]840-a tall and slender young man , with flaxen hair and a moustache almost white , and the work [he]121-kemp was upon would earn [him]121-kemp , [he]121-kemp hoped , the fellowship of [the Royal Society]841-the royal society , so highly did [he]121-kemp think of it .

And [his]121-kemp eye , presently wandering from [his]121-kemp work , caught the sunset blazing at the back of [the hill]592-the hill that is over against [his]121-kemp own . For a minute perhaps [he]121-kemp sat , pen in mouth , admiring the rich golden colour above the crest , and then [his]121-kemp attention was attracted by the little figure of [a man]1463-a man , inky black , running over the hill - brow towards [him]121-kemp . [He]1463-a man was [a shortish little man]844-a shortish little man , and [he]1463-a man wore a high hat , and [he]1463-a man was running so fast that [his]1463-a man legs verily twinkled .

" [Another of those fools]1642-another of those fools , "[121-kemp] said [Dr. Kemp]121-kemp . By [the man]345-the man pounded , and as [he]345-the man ran [he]345-the man chinked like a well - filled purse that is tossed to and fro . CHAPTER XVII . [DR . KEMP S VISITOR

Dr. Kemp]121-kemp had continued writing in [[his]121-kemp study]836-his study until the shots aroused [him]121-kemp . Crack , crack , crack , [they]951-they came one after the other .

" [Hullo]127-hullo ! "[121-kemp] said [Dr. Kemp]121-kemp , putting [his]121-kemp pen into [his]121-kemp mouth again and listening . " Who s letting off revolvers in [Burdock]122-port burdock ? What are [the asses]1664-the asses at now ? "[121-kemp]

[He]121-kemp went to the south window , threw it up , and leaning out stared down on the network of windows , beaded gas - lamps and [shops]827-shops , with [its]953-its black interstices of roof and yard that made up [the town]872-the town at night . " Looks like a crowd down [the hill]592-the hill , "[121-kemp] [he]121-kemp said , " by [The Cricketers]129-the cricketers , "[121-kemp] and remained watching . [Thence]955-thence [his]121-kemp eyes wandered over [the town]872-the town to far away where the ships lights shone , and [the pier]957-the pier glowed a little illuminated , facetted pavilion like a gem of yellow light . The moon in its first quarter hung over [the westward hill]958-the westward hill , and the stars were clear and almost tropically bright .

After five minutes , during which [his]121-kemp mind had travelled into a remote speculation of social conditions of the future , and lost itself at last over the time dimension , [Dr. Kemp]121-kemp roused [himself]121-kemp with a sigh , pulled down the window again , and returned to [his]121-kemp writing desk .

It must have been about an hour after this that the front - door bell rang . [He]121-kemp had been writing slackly , and with intervals of abstraction , since the shots . [He]121-kemp sat listening . [He]121-kemp heard [the servant]959-the servant answer the door , and waited for [her]959-the servant feet on the staircase , but [she]959-the servant did not come . " Wonder what that was , "[121-kemp] said [Dr. Kemp]121-kemp .

[He]121-kemp tried to resume [his]121-kemp work , failed , got up , went [downstairs]377-downstairs from [[his]121-kemp study]836-his study to [the landing]368-the landing , rang , and called over the balustrade to [the housemaid]963-the housemaid as [she]963-the housemaid appeared in [the hall below]964-the hall below . " Was that a letter ? "[121-kemp] [he]121-kemp asked .

" Only a runaway ring , [sir]1417-sir , "[963-the housemaid] [she]963-the housemaid answered .

" [I]121-kemp m restless to - night , "[121-kemp] [he]121-kemp said to [himself]121-kemp . [He]121-kemp went back to [[his]121-kemp study]836-his study , and this time attacked [his]121-kemp work resolutely . In a little while [he]121-kemp was hard at work again , and the only sounds in [the room]1421-the room were the ticking of the clock and the subdued shrillness of [his]121-kemp quill , hurrying in the very centre of the circle of light [his]121-kemp lampshade threw on [his]121-kemp table .

It was two o clock before [Dr. Kemp]121-kemp had finished [his]121-kemp work for the night . [He]121-kemp rose , yawned , and went [downstairs]377-downstairs to bed . [He]121-kemp had already removed [his]121-kemp coat and vest , when [he]121-kemp noticed that [he]121-kemp was thirsty . [He]121-kemp took a candle and went down to [the dining - room]968-the dining - room in search of a syphon and whiskey .

[Dr. Kemp]121-kemp s scientific pursuits have made [him]121-kemp [a very observant man]969-a very observant man , and as [he]121-kemp recrossed [the hall]346-the hall , [he]121-kemp noticed a dark spot on the linoleum near the mat at the foot of [the stairs]971-the stairs . [He]121-kemp went on [upstairs]256-upstairs , and then it suddenly occurred to [him]121-kemp to ask [himself]121-kemp what the spot on the linoleum might be . Apparently some subconscious element was at work . At any rate , [he]121-kemp turned with [his]121-kemp burden , went back to [the hall]346-the hall , put down the syphon and whiskey , and bending down , touched the spot . Without any great surprise [he]121-kemp found it had the stickiness and colour of drying blood .

[He]121-kemp took up [his]121-kemp burden again , and returned [upstairs]256-upstairs , looking about [him]121-kemp and trying to account for the blood - spot . On [the landing]368-the landing [he]121-kemp saw something and stopped astonished . The door - handle of [[his]121-kemp own room]407-his own room was blood - stained .

[He]121-kemp looked at [his]121-kemp own hand . It was quite clean , and then [he]121-kemp remembered that the door of [[his]121-kemp room]296-his room had been open when [he]121-kemp came down from [[his]121-kemp study]836-his study , and that consequently [he]121-kemp had not touched the handle at all . [He]121-kemp went straight into [[his]121-kemp room]296-his room , [his]121-kemp face quite calm perhaps a trifle more resolute than usual . [His]121-kemp glance , wandering inquisitively , fell on the bed . On the counterpane was a mess of blood , and the sheet had been torn . [He]121-kemp had not noticed this before because [he]121-kemp had walked straight to the dressing - table . On the further side the bedclothes were depressed as if [someone]428-someone had been recently sitting there .

Then [he]121-kemp had an odd impression that [he]121-kemp had heard a low voice say , " [Good Heavens]130-good heavens ! [Kemp]121-kemp ! "[121-kemp] But [Dr. Kemp]121-kemp was [no believer in voices]981-no believer in voices .

[He]121-kemp stood staring at the tumbled sheets . Was that really a voice ? [He]121-kemp looked about again , but noticed nothing further than the disordered and blood - stained bed . Then [he]121-kemp distinctly heard a movement across [the room]1421-the room , near the wash - hand stand . [All men]983-all men , however highly educated , retain [some superstitious inklings]984-some superstitious inklings . The feeling that is called " eerie "[121-kemp] came upon [him]121-kemp . [He]121-kemp closed the door of [the room]1421-the room , came forward to the dressing - table , and put down [his]121-kemp burdens . [He]121-kemp stared at this in amazement . It was an empty bandage , a bandage properly tied but quite empty . [He]121-kemp would have advanced to grasp it , but a touch arrested [him]121-kemp , and a voice speaking quite close to [him]121-kemp .

" [I]121-kemp ll see what there is to eat [downstairs]377-downstairs , "[121-kemp] said [Kemp]121-kemp . " Not much , [I]121-kemp m afraid . "[121-kemp]

After [he]121-kemp had done eating , and [he]121-kemp made a heavy meal , [the Invisible Man]150-the invisible man demanded a cigar . [He]150-the invisible man bit the end savagely before [Kemp]121-kemp could find a knife , and cursed when the outer leaf loosened . " This blessed gift of smoking ! "[121-kemp] [he]121-kemp said , and puffed vigorously . " [I]121-kemp m lucky to have fallen upon [you]121-kemp , [Kemp]121-kemp . But the story was not told that night . [The Invisible Man]105-the invisible man s wrist was growing painful ; [he]105-the invisible man was feverish , exhausted , and [his]105-the invisible man mind came round to brood upon [his]105-the invisible man chase down [the hill]592-the hill and the struggle about [the inn]157-the inn .
